TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs is absent from question time today. He is addressing the New South Wales annual state conference of the RSL in Sydney. The Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel will answer questions on his behalf. The Minister for Family Services is also absent from question time today. —My question is to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware that the Yellow Pages survey of 1,200 small businesses, released today, shows that Australia's small business sector sees no sign of economic recovery and that more than 80 per cent of businesses surveyed see the economy as being in a recession or at a standstill? Is he also aware that the survey reports that small business proprietors' confidence has reached its lowest point since August 1993 and that support for the government's policies has plummeted from 42 per cent to 14 per cent in 12 months? As the survey postdates his statement to this parliament on small business on 24 March last, what additional action is the government planning to restore some level of confidence in the sector?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the report, and can I say to the small business community of Australia that, unlike the previous government, this government will not arrogantly dismiss the concerns of small business on the basis of, `What are you going on about?' or `You have never had it so good.'

ANSWER.PARA: I remain very conscious of the fact that the small business community of Australia was very badly savaged by the recession of the late 1980s and the early 1990s, and we have taken a number of measures to remedy that situation. The Leader of the Opposition gives me the opportunity of reminding the parliament and the small business community of Australia that since we have been in office there have been reductions in small business interest rates of between 1½ and two per cent.

May I repeat the call that I made yesterday to the major banks of Australia that under no circumstances should the major banks of Australia discriminate against small business. We regard as quite unacceptable the notion that interest rate reductions should be afforded to big business but not to small business.

The Leader of the Opposition said that the Yellow Pages survey postdated an announcement that I made in the parliament about small business measures. I remind him that it predates the federal budget, which was a major confidence booster to small business.
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It also predates the most recent reduction in interest rates but, most importantly, I hear calls from the other side of the parliament: what are we going to do about it? I might well return that and say: why don't you agree to pass the latest unfair dismissal changes? If you are really interested in doing something about small business, you would do something to assist those very small firms in Australia. You are talking about firms that employ fewer than 15 people. You are talking about the heart and soul of small business. What they continue to complain about is the unfair dismissal laws, and the refusal of the Australian Labor Party to support our proposals in that area demonstrates that since the last election the Labor Party has learnt absolutely nothing on this front.

ANSWER.PARA: I say to the small business community of Australia: the interest rate changes of recent months are working their way through the economy. They will have beneficial effects over coming months. The capital gains tax changes will come into operation on 1 July. I say to the small business community of Australia: we understand your problems. We don't sneer at you. We don't dismiss your problems. We sympathise with you, and you will never get from this Prime Minister an arrogant dismissal on the basis of `You have never had it so good' and `What are you going on about?'

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Is the Treasurer aware of further movements in home loan interest rates over the past 24 hours? What would such a movement indicate about the government's policy of delivering consumer benefits through fostering competition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Lindsay for her question. I can inform the House that, in the last hour, the ANZ Bank has led the way with another reduction in the variable home loan rate. ANZ today announced a further reduction in home loan interest rates: the standard variable home loan rate for owner occupiers will fall to 6.99 per cent from tomorrow—the lowest home rates generally available to mortgage borrowers since 1969, since man first walked on the moon.

ANSWER.PARA: The reduction in the home loan rates is a result of the reductions in the home loan rates from when this government came to office. When this government came to office, the standard variable home loan rate was 10.5 per cent and it is now 6.99 per cent—a reduction of 3.55 percentage points since this government was elected. In interest savings on a $100,000 loan, that represents an interest saving of $292 a month—after tax.

Mr Speaker, if you want to compare that to the Labor Party's record, in 1989 the Keating Labor Party, of which the Leader of the Opposition, his deputy and his new industry spokesman were members, had home mortgage rates at 17 per cent. On a $100,000 home loan, that gave you an interest bill of $1,417 a month. On the ANZ rate offered today, you would make a saving against that of $834 a month—$834 a month from where the Labor Party had home mortgage rates in 1989.

It was the government's policy, which was opposed on every point by the Labor Party, to lock in monetary targets and low inflation with an agreement between the Reserve Bank and the government. The Labor Party threatened to sue. It was our policy to turn from a $10.3 billion deficit to a $1.6 billion surplus. The Labor Party voted against all of those measures. It was our policy to say that if we kept wages down we would get benefits in relation to interest rates. The Labor Party went into the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and tried to have an increase in wages which would have been unsustainable.

This is the party of savings, low deficits, reduced debt and low interest rates; and that is the party of high deficits, high debt, high interest rates, high taxes and no small business accommodation. For people in the electorate of Lindsay, the battlers of Lindsay, represented by the coalition—because the coalition government now represents blue‐collar workers in this country—there is no better benefit you can deliver to them than reducing their home mortgage fees. The coalition government set out on an economic strategy to do that. The benefits are there. They are there for home buyers. They are there for the electorate of Lindsay. They are there for small business. The best that can be said for the Labor Party is that they never succeeded in their campaign to stop these improvements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to his tabling speech in response to the Bell committee report when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . we promised small business a new deal at the last election and we are delivering on that commitment . . .

In light of today's Yellow Pages Small Business Index findings that less than 10 per cent of all small business operators thought that the government's Bell report initiatives would improve their situation, does this not confirm that your government is hopelessly out of touch with the real needs of the small business community and that it has failed to deliver on your commitment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Cunningham for the question. He draws on the Yellow Pages report. I am very happy to extend the practice. That same report says that 62 per cent of businesses now expect to expand. Sixty per cent of businesses are confident about the future. The last time I went to the polls, 60 per cent was a pretty good majority. It was the two‐party preferred coalition vote in the whole of Queensland. Sixty‐one per cent of businesses expect an improvement in profitability over the next 12 months. That is the Yellow Pages survey.

ANSWER.PARA: The member for Cunningham invites me to reflect on whether I have delivered on my promises to the small business community at the last election. What were they? The first of them was to do something about the provisional tax uplift factor. If my memory serves me correctly, we have delivered that in full. The next was to do something about capital gains tax concessions for small business. If my memory serves me correctly, we have overdelivered on that particular commitment.

I remember that we said that we were going to change the industrial relations laws of Australia. If we had been allowed to do so by the Senate, we would have delivered 100 per cent of those. We delivered about 80 to 90 per cent of them as a result of obstruction by the Labor Party and the Democrats in the Senate. We said that we were going to do something about paperwork. We have done that.

We said that we were going to do something about the unfair dismissal laws. We have greatly reformed the unfair dismissal laws. We would like to go a little bit further, but of course the Labor Party and the Democrats will not allow us. The Labor Party and the Democrats do not listen to those small business men and women of Australia who would like to have the freedom to take people on probation for 12 months and if it does not work out to let them go. There is nothing wrong with that. Anybody who understands small business will know that.

Another thing that the member for Cunningham invites me to refer to is the impact of reduced interest rates on small business. It is undeniable, as the Treasurer said, that if the former government had been returned to office we would not have had a deficit reduction strategy. We therefore would not have had the falls in interest rates that have occurred over the last 14 months. Although the falls in interest rates for small business are less satisfactory than they are for home buyers, they are nonetheless real, they are tangible and they are valuable.

The important thing for the small business community to hear out of all of this is not what the member for Cunningham is saying but to understand that they now have a government that understands them. You now have a government that is not arrogant. You now have a government that is sympathetic to small business. You now have a government that is in touch with small business. I understand that it is taking time for the benefits of those changes to work through. One of them, for example, the capital gains tax changes, will not come into operation on 1 July.

Can I say in conclusion that we are in touch with small business. We understand their problems. We realise the pain that was inflicted on small business by the recession. We will continue to develop policies to assist them and, the Senate and the Labor Party and the Democrats willing, we could deliver them out of the bondage of that unfair dismissal restriction if only the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats would agree to pass it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer advise the House what today's capital expenditure figures say about the budget forecasts for investment and what they suggest about prospects for continued growth and job creation?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. The March quarter capital expenditure survey supports the budget forecast for strong growth in business investment in 1996-97. Expectations for total capital spending in 1996-97 continued to rise in the March quarter to be nearly 40 per cent higher than the first estimate for 1996-97. Total business investment rose strongly in constant price terms in the March quarter to its highest level since the survey commenced in the June quarter of 1987.

BREAK.PARA: Total capital spending in the first three quarters of 1996-97 is 21 per cent higher than it was for the equivalent period in 1995-96. Equipment spending has reached its highest level in constant price terms since the survey began. While growth in building investment rebounded strongly following falls in the previous two quarters, it is now close to its historical high. The outlook for total business investment in 1997‐98 is positive, with the second estimate for total capital expenditure being 15 per cent higher than the first estimates taken in January‐February.

What does that tell us about the Australian economy? What it tells us about the Australian economy is that business investment is very strong—at record levels. This is coming at a time when interest rates are being reduced and are at historical lows. It is coming at a time when the budget is turning from deficit to surplus. We now have the Australian budget on a path, by the year 2000‐01, to halve the debt to GDP ratio—to halve the Commonwealth debt to GDP ratio. The underlying inflation rate is projected to be two per cent in the forthcoming year, with a consumer price index of one per cent.

You would go a long way to find business conditions which were as conducive to investment as these are. We have low inflation—inflation back at levels we have not seen since the 1970s—a budget spinning back into surplus, a Commonwealth debt to GDP ratio halving to the year 2000, home mortgage rates the lowest they have been since the 1960s, and business rates falling accordingly. This is a growth, low inflation, strong investment economy. That is the kind of economy which Australian business needs to see.

I want to make it clear on behalf of this government that it is not this government's purpose to go back to the boom-bust failures of the Keating Labor administration. It is the purpose of this government to put in place the big structural changes which will deliver sustained and sustainable growth on a decade basis. With low inflation and growth on a decade basis we can repair our financial situation, get our debt down and create that business investment environment.

Today's private new capital expenditure survey results are consistent with that. They indicate the opportunities for business investment in the Australian community. Investment equals jobs and it is investment which will drive job creation in this growth, low inflation economy, which is confirmed by the CAPEX figures today.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question follows the answer that the Treasurer has given, but it is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, are you aware that in the small business index published today that, for small business, capital expenditure growth is anticipated to be negative and expectations are lower? Did you also see the quote from John Marsden, the consulting economist, who said, `There are now more small businesses across Australia seeing federal government policies as negative than they see as positive'? That is a staggering result for a government which prides itself on being pro‐small business. Prime Minister, when are you going to wake up to the real opinion that small business has of you?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not read every detail of the survey, but can I say in reply to the Leader of the Opposition that no amount of selective disaggregation of capital investment figures can alter the fact that we are living in an economy now which is growing in confidence every day. We are living in an economy where every day the business community is seeing the benefit of falling interest rates. Every day is seeing the benefit of falling inflation, every day is seeing the benefit of rising levels of capital investment and every day is seeing the benefit of having in power a government that is willing over a period of time to lay the foundations for sustained economic growth.

ANSWER.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition can quote all of the surveys he wishes. Nothing can alter the undeniable fact that he left the new government with a deficit of $10.5 billion. In the first term, we will have turned that deficit into a surplus of $1.6 billion. The expectational effects of that are already being felt. Why else is it that interest rates have fallen so dramatically over the last 14 months? Why is it that people feel confident enough to invest in business? Why is it that increasingly people see the low interest rate, low inflation economic circumstances of Australia as being very propitious for business?
As I said in my answer to the earlier question, I understand the hurt that is continuing to be experienced by sections of the Australian business community.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you going to do about it?
—The member for Hotham!

—Unlike those who once occupied the treasury bench in Australia, I am not arrogantly insensitive to small business. I do not wave my finger at small business and tell them that if they cannot stand the heat they ought to get out of the kitchen. I do not say to small business, when they are paying astronomically high interest rates, as they were under Keating Labor, `You have never had it so good.' I do not say to them, `What are you going on about?' I understand their problems. I have taken a number of very significant steps to ease them and I believe that in the fullness of time, as the benefits of those policies flow through, that will increasingly be seen by the small business community of Australia.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer, and it follows the previous question. Given the federal government's strong commitment to Australian small business as the job generators and economic backbone of our nation, can the Treasurer outline to the House what has been achieved by the Commonwealth in this crucial area thus far and current moves to assist small business even further?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister for the economic past, the member for Hotham—

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Crean interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I warn the member for Hotham.

—Nostalgically looking back for a past when the ACTU used to run the country, aren't you? The member for Hotham says, `What about the index?' I have already said in the House that I think that the Small Business Index is not something to live or die by. But I do read it. I know that the opposition lives and dies by it. I do read it because I know that the day the Yellow Pages Small Business Index comes out—you can pick it; it is like clockwork—you will have the opposition up referring to it.

ANSWER.PARA: I took a little bit of a look at it myself. I had a look at the confidence trends, where it asked small business whether they were confident or worried about the future. Sixty per cent were totally confident; those who were worried, 20 per cent. What is that—three to one?

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you look at page 9?

—I looked right through it, old son, and I will walk you through it bit by bit. The economy a year from now—better, 30 per cent; worse, 13 per cent. Small business was asked what their prime concerns were.

ANSWER.PARA: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they were not concerned about Labor because they did not think there was any threat from them. Their prime concern—second, lack of sales at 21 per cent; third, cash flow at 11 per cent. What was their No. 1 prime concern at 28 per cent? None. The No. 1 concern that came in on this survey at 28 per cent was none.

ANSWER.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition referred in his question to one of these positive‐negative indicators. He said, `Oh, well, attitudes to the federal government policies were minus six.' That is what you said in your last question. Is that right? When you detract those who say `work against' from those who are supportive, you get minus six. You referred to that in your last question.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you refer to my last question?

—You did, you did. I decided I would go back and get a bit of a historical perspective. The Leader of the Opposition refers to minus six. In February of 1996, who was in government? In February of 1996, when small business in this same survey—remember you are complaining about minus six—was asked whether government policies were supportive or worked against small business, the reply in February 1996 was minus 51 per cent. And you get up here and you trumpet minus six.

ANSWER.PARA: Somebody who trumpets minus six against minus 51 is probably somebody who ran around during the 1996 election campaign saying there was no deficit. Do you recall that? It did not exist. This was the man who walked around during the election campaign saying that the accounts of Australia were in balance, were in surplus. That was the Minister for Finance during the 1996 election. I have said before that there are only two explanations for that, and one of them is incompetence.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the minister update the House on what measures have been taken as a result of suspected outbreaks of the fire blight disease in Melbourne and Adelaide? In particular, can the minister indicate what steps are being taken to ascertain how the disease originated in the gardens, whether it is the strain of erwinia to which apples and pears are susceptible, and can he alleviate the concerns of many fruit growers in my electorate who believe it may have been deliberately introduced by New Zealanders?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and recognise that it is of real concern to him and to the people of his electorate and to many others in this place. Obviously, it is of very real interest to establish how it might have got here. We will be actively exploring all possible pathways for its entry. At this very early stage, it seems reasonable to conclude that it has probably been here for quite a while. However, if something untoward is established over the next little while, we will certainly take the matter further in that regard.

ANSWER.PARA: I can say that we acted very quickly indeed, particularly in the initial days of the problem, in concert with the Victorian Department of Conservation and Natural Resources to cordon off the area and to seek as much information as we could about how real the problem is. At the moment we have people marching around no less than 8,000 kilometres of trees around the place as we seek to ascertain whether in fact it exists anywhere outside the Botanic Gardens in Melbourne and the Botanic Gardens in Adelaide. We sincerely hope not.

The other concern, and I dare say a matter of great importance, is that the test results in both New Zealand and in Australia have been somewhat inconclusive. In the interests of the industry, we are assuming at this stage that it is fire blight, although some hope is emerging that it is not a particularly virulent strain. We have sent samples to the leading institute in Germany in this regard, the Max Planck Institute, where Professor Klaus Geider will be seeking to identify—at arm's length and totally independently—the exact nature of the problem. He will be visiting us here shortly to again report to us and also work through our testing procedures to establish their veracity in this country.

The situation in relation to New Zealand is that their minister has apologised for the behaviour of officers in his employ. We have indicated that we will continue to examine possible pathways for entry and take it further if something untoward were to emerge, although at this stage our priority is on containing the problem and eliminating it if we can. It would be helpful, I must say, if some of their scientists were not to appear, as they have, rather smug about the discomfort and the possible misfortune for Australian fruit producers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Employment: Work for the Dole Initiative

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the very effective Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. People in my electorate of Fisher, and indeed throughout the country, are eagerly awaiting the implementation of the government's work for the dole initiative. Does the government have any information about the likely effects of work for the dole projects on the employment prospects of participants? Can the minister outline other comments made regarding the work for the dole initiative?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Schools, Vocational Education and Training; Minister Assisting the Minister for Finance for Privatisation

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Fisher for his question. It is indeed true that the work for the dole initiative has achieved great community support, probably nowhere more so than amongst young Australians, who see the opportunities that the scheme will give them to make a contribution to their communities. It is an initiative which will provide lasting benefits for many thousands of young people in communities around Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Members will be aware that the government's work for the dole legislation passed through the House of Representatives last night. It did so, of course, despite the opposition of the Australian Labor Party. The differences between the government and the opposition on this matter could now not be clearer. The government supports work for the dole; the Labor Party opposes it.

Support for the work for the dole initiative also extends well into the business community. A recent national survey by Morgan and Banks of some 3,200 employers around Australia found that nearly three in five businesses would be more willing to employ someone with experience from work for the dole than without it. Indeed, Mr Geoff Morgan, Joint Managing Director of Morgan and Banks, stated that at a minimum `work for the dole allows people to learn workplace skills and develop a sense of self-worth as an employee'. That is the attitude of the business community in Australia. It is, of course, not the attitude of the Labor Party, which has consistently ignored and denigrated the views of the business community.

Now the Labor Party has come clean on work for the dole. It opposes work for the dole. It wants a return to its cruel and deceitful short-term training programs that demoralised so many young Australians, but it opposes the government's initiative and the fair and equitable character of work for the dole.

The government and the Australian people believe that if Australians are working hard to provide support for unemployed people then it is fair to require the person receiving that support to put something back into their community. The work for the dole scheme will include both compulsory and voluntary pilots. We believe that is fair and equitable. The Labor Party does not.

Let me make it quite clear to the Labor Party and to the Australian people that if the Labor Party tries to destroy the work for the dole scheme in the Senate then the government will put that legislation straight back into the Senate again. The Labor Party will have to stand up before the Australian people and tell them that it is opposed to work for the dole. Once again, it will have demonstrated that it is completely out of touch with young people, with Australian businesses and with Australian communities. You are opposed to work for the dole. Your opposition is now out in the open and you will have to live by that decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs. The minister would be aware that the Yellow Pages Small Business Index, released today, shows that the government's small business strategy is a manifest failure with small business confidence at its lowest level since August 1993, with 80 per cent of small businesses seeing the economy as being in recession or at a standstill and with less than 10 per cent of all small business believing that the government's initiatives will improve the situation. Will the government now give an unequivocal guarantee to accept the recommendations of the fair trading inquiry report, released yesterday, to give legislative protection to the small business sector?

—I am delighted that the opposition have finally decided to ask me some questions in regard to this survey. I find it fascinating in a lot of ways that they have finally discovered the worth of this survey—in fact, that they finally believe in the survey. I would like to remind them first of what the then parliamentary secretary to the industry minister said on this matter just on two years ago.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. In deference to your statement to this House yesterday, you did indicate that ministers would have to be relevant to questions posed to them. I specifically asked the minister about the fair trading inquiry report released yesterday, and we would like to hear the government's response to that question.
—There is no point of order.

—Ted Lindsay was the then representative and he said the index was `politically biased'. Those are not my words; they are his words. He was your spokesman. He also said, `The report has no integrity.' Your man said that the report had no integrity, yet now you are holding up the report as being something very special. Let us look further at what the report states. In relation to current federal government policies the survey asked: `Do you believe that they are supportive or have they worked against small business?' What did 60 per cent say? Sixty per cent said they had worked against small business. But during what period? The period was from May 1993 to February 1996. Sixty per cent said that your policies worked against them!

—Mr Speaker, again I go to the issue of relevance in respect of the question that was asked about the report of the fair trading inquiry, tabled in this place yesterday. The minister is referring to a specific table in the index. As it is said here, more small business proprietors see federal government policies working against rather than for small business.
—I thank the honourable member for Cunningham. There is no point of order. The minister is addressing the question.

—In addition to that, on the importance of the survey, the February survey carried a question about the impact of lower interest rates. The survey asked, `Have lower interest rates had an impact on your business?' Fifty‐seven per cent said yes. Do we find any question in regard to interest rates in the current survey? No. The most important thing about small business is interest rates, and this survey completely missed it. It did not say that we have made enormous steps.

BREAK.PARA: But, going to the point, let us look at the things that are important to small business. If we look at the improvement in the concern factor—and my colleague the Treasurer mentioned the concern factor—if we go back to the original concern factor, there has been `a major improvement'. Concern in regard to sales and increased cash flow—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Once again, the question was about the report tabled yesterday. The minister has not even mentioned its title. When it was tabled in this place yesterday, he did not bother to put out a press release to give us an inkling of his intentions.
—We are not going to debate the issue. There is no point of order. I would like the minister to now address the substance of the question.

—The substance of importance to small business is cash flow, sales and, of course, work. Getting to the point, what is important is that this particular survey has picked a marked improvement in the concern of small business. They have in fact seen a marked improvement from—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The minister is defying your ruling to come to the substance of the question. That's it, Geoff; have a look at it so you know what it looks like.
—Order! The member for Cunningham will resume his seat.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. In the preface to the question, there was an unambiguous reference to the report and the Yellow Pages index. On the basis that yesterday in your statement you made it clear that if the opposition insists on providing prefaces to questions the government is entitled to respond to those remarks in a preface and that it is relevant for a minister to do so, this fourth point of order is entirely spurious and the minister is clearly within order.
—I thank the Leader of the House. The minister will now address the substance of the question.

—All this is filibustering by the opposition. In regard to small business, as the Prime Minister just mentioned, unlike the opposition, we do feel for small business; we are out there listening to their concerns.

BREAK.PARA: In regard to the report, the House would be very well aware that the previous report into small business by the previous government—called the Beddall report, I might add—was two years in the making and it took you 11 months to respond to. In fact, I commissioned this report in May of last year. So we have brought down the report within 12 months, and we will respond within three months.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Can the minister inform the House of the state of access to health services by people living in rural Australia—for example, in areas like northern Victoria? How is the government's commitment to improving the health of Australians living in rural areas being implemented?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. The government is absolutely determined to give rural people a fair go in access to health services, and in a country as vast as Australia that can be very difficult. We were able to have a number of new initiatives in the budget that I find very exciting. The first is that we are looking at a range of innovative service delivery mechanisms that will try to extend the reach of funding into country areas.
—I would hate to see you bored.
—Order! I warn the member for Wills.

—This country has a very great capacity to utilise telemedicine and other modalities, and in that way we can lead the world. We are extending the advanced specialists training post program to get more specialist training in country areas. A lot is said about GPs in country areas, but not much is talked about specialists. Country people need access to physicians, surgeons and obstetricians just as much as city people, and extending the advanced training post program will help address that. With rural health research, we are taking a much more strategic approach to that.

ANSWER.PARA: With obstetrics, one of the quiet problems of rural health, we are going to look at alternate ways of funding services in rural areas. One of the most difficult issues that rural women face is getting access to obstetric services. The program we have announced in the budget will look at things such as the limited professional indemnity cover, a lack of training and continuing education for general practitioners, difficulties of getting locums and a lack of peer support.

There is one further issue that we announced in last year's budget that I can inform the House about, and that is the university departments of rural health. These are designed to very simply try to link the gap that currently exists in undergraduate medical and allied health training. At the moment there is no real mechanism to give medical students and other students who wish to pursue a career in country areas the capacity to have a lot more on the ground experience before they graduate. In the last nine months we have announced that there will be centres at Broken Hill, building on the Broken Hill public health unit, and at Mount Isa.

The thing about these centres is that, if they are centres of excellence and parts of university departments, it will mean that someone can actually plan an academic career in rural health—something that is almost impossible now. Going to the country is often committing academic suicide. If there are university outposts of six places around Australia, they will address this real deficiency. We deliberately did not just call these departments of rural medicine, because health is more than medicine and it is not just designed to meet the needs of the medical profession—although that is a big part of it. The public health unit at Broken Hill and the Mount Isa unit, for example, will have a very substantial role in Aboriginal health.

BREAK.PARA: We have now made a decision on the location of the remaining four units around Australia. The first will be in the honourable member's electorate located at Shepparton. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:

(1) recognises that today, 27 May 1997, is the 30th anniversary of the referendum that amended section 51(xxvi) of the Constitution, which gave the Commonwealth the power to make special laws for the people of any race, in particular Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people;
(2) reaffirms the support for the outcome of that referendum, which received the unprecedented support of 90.77 per cent of the Australian people;

(3) recognises the need for the legislative and other powers of the Commonwealth to be used to address the profound economic and social disadvantage continuing to be suffered by indigenous Australians—with specific emphasis on and practical measures to address health, housing, education and employment;

(4) supports the reconciliation process as being important to all Australians and recognises the need to acknowledge past injustices, but emphasises the value of a cooperative effort to build a better future for all Australians; and

(5) supports the request that the plaque symbolically commemorating the 1967 referendum, unveiled today in Melbourne by the Governor‐General and Dr Faith Bandler at the Australian Reconciliation Convention, be appropriately housed within Old Parliament House.

Mr Speaker, I would hope that this is a motion that could draw the support of all members of the House. I hope it is a motion that could not only draw the support of the members of the Australian Labor Party but also all Independent members of the House, because it does contain a number of unambiguous statements of fundamental principle.

It recognises that in 1967, in a quite unprecedented fashion, the Australian people joined in saying—very loudly and to the effect of over 90 per cent of those who participated in the referendum—that, unambiguously, they wished Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders to be treated as full citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia; that they wanted them in every way to be given that respect. They also resolved, in passing that referendum, to clothe the parliament of the Commonwealth—this parliament—with the power to make laws for those people.

If the 1967 referendum was about anything it was about giving power to the Commonwealth government on behalf of the Commonwealth parliament to do practical things to address the disadvantage of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The people of Australia made a judgment in 1967 that the then existing arrangements to assist Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people were not working effectively and that they could only be made to work more effectively if the Commonwealth parliament were given the power. In a sense, the motivation for the 1967 referendum and the belief that the passage of the 1967 referendum was necessary for the benefit of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is a guide to the policies that should now be followed if we are really committed to assisting those people.

Our approach as a government to the process of reconciliation is very much guided by and heavily influenced by the spirit of the 1967 referendum. If the 1967 referendum spoke of anything it spoke of a need to remedy in a practical way the disadvantage of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. If you want a unanimity of view within the Australian community or a near unanimity of view within the Australian community on issues relating to the indigenous people then you must look at areas of disadvantage in issues such as health, housing, employment and education. Our approach to reconciliation is very much guided by our strong belief that the path to effective reconciliation lies in remedying those areas of disadvantage and through that giving to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people the full capacity to enjoy freedom of opportunity as Australian people.

In the remarks that I made to the Reconciliation Convention yesterday, I deliberately said, and I repeat it in the House today, that we believe that the essence of reconciliation lies not in symbolic gestures—although some of them are important; this motion in a sense is a symbolic gesture. It is important on these issues that the parliament, as far as possible, speak with one voice—not in overblown rhetoric but in a practical determination to address the areas of disadvantage that indigenous people suffer.

I have said repeatedly that anybody who argues that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are not as a group more profoundly disadvantaged than other sections of the Australian community are flying in the face of reality. People who argue that are substituting fiction for fact. They are substituting selective anecdotes for irrefutable statistical proof and they are also ignoring the realities that are around us to see.

That does not mean to say that every Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander in Australia is disadvantaged. It does not mean to say that some of the programs over recent years that have been directed to curing their disadvantage have not involved substantial elements of waste and failure. That does not alter the fact that they remain a very disad vantaged group. Even a cursory examination of their health situation, a cursory examination of their employment opportunities, a cursory examination of their educational opportunities rather than educational achievements—because when given the opportunity they achieve and achieve very effectively—would refute that proposition. I say on behalf of the government that we accept, we always have and, until the disadvantage is removed, we will continue to believe, that as a group they are disadvantaged. That has to be the cornerstone of a practical understanding of the policies that are brought to bear on their situation.

We make no apology for the fact that in some areas we have followed somewhat different policies from those of the former government. I am not going to use this as an occasion to go through the policies of the former government. I think this House understands that there are areas where we disagree. I accept that there are many people in the Labor Party who are committed to removing indigenous disadvantage and I am not going to argue the toss about that in a motion such as this, but I invite them to accept that there are many on our side who are equally committed.

I invite all members of this House to put aside any kind of moral preoccupation with their position on matters affecting indigenous people. I ask all members of this House to accept that nobody has any kind of moral monopoly of concern about indigenous people. I put to you, Mr Speaker, that the policies that we are embarked upon, in our view, conscientiously represent the most effective way of achieving outcomes.

We are not obsessed with symbolism. We are concerned, though, with practical outcomes. That is why we have put such an enormous focus in recent months since we came to office on addressing areas of disadvantage. It is why we believe that by addressing that disadvantage we can best give to indigenous people their full opportunity as Australian citizens. It is why, despite the necessities of the time, we have quarantined from any expenditure restraint some of the critical areas in relation to indigenous education. We have in fact expanded expenditure in a number of areas. I am very happy to say that in the last budget we announced a significant expansion of programs which are designed to help Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people succeed in their own businesses and generate a greater sense of economic independence and a greater sense of self-empowerment.

The purpose of the 1967 referendum was to give expression to a view that it was completely unacceptable morally and in the sense of our dignity as a nation to continue to regard the first Australians as anything other than full participants in the Australian community. Although indigenous people had had the vote before 1967, they had not been counted in the census and the Commonwealth lacked adequate power to address their very real needs.

In the years that have gone by since 1967, it is worth recording the progress that has been made and the contribution that has been made from a number of governments towards improving the situation of indigenous people. Regrettably, because of the ferocity of debate that often surrounds matters relating to indigenous people, the community could be forgiven for believing that no progress has been made in any area. I think that would do a grievous disservice not only to the truth but also to the contributions of several governments of both political persuasions to tackling the problem.

BREAK.PARA: For example, the community employment development projects were established in 1977. The community housing and infrastructure program was established shortly afterwards. The health infrastructure policy priority project was also established. The Aboriginal health services have provided much needed health assistance to indigenous people. The national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy began in 1990 and it includes Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education strategic initiative programs and also the Abstudy program. The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation was established in 1991 and the establishment of that body, elected by indigenous people, was designed to represent their views and interests and to implement programs that addressed their needs.

There continues to be within the community, not least within the indigenous community itself, significant debate about the value of the ATSIC system. When coming to power the government decided to retain it. In conformity with our election undertakings, there were changes made and increased levels of accountability imposed, but the structure was retained.

It would not be possible to do justice to this subject without saying one or two things about two issues that are very much in the public arena so far as indigenous affairs are concerned. The first of those, of course, is the Native Title Act amendments, which are under notice from the government at the present time. In 1992 the High Court of Australia brought down the Mabo decision, which threw out the old terra nullius doctrine and substituted for it a recognition of the survival in certain circumstances of native title, including on the mainland of Australia. As a consequence of that, the Commonwealth Parliament enacted a Native Title Act in 1993 and at the end of last year the High Court of Australia brought down its decision in the Wik case.

I know that the government's response to the Wik decision has generated considerable opposition, not only within some sections—I stress some sections—of the rural community of Australia, but also within the indigenous community of Australia. Can I say to the indigenous people of Australia that I understand why they are opposed to the amendments that we have put forward, but can I put to them and can I put through this parliament to the Australian people that the plan that we have devised to deal with the consequences of the Wik decision and also to deal with the unsatisfactory features of the Native Title Act is a fair and balanced plan. It is true that it does represent a significant winding back of the situation that obtained under the law immediately after the decision of the High Court in the Wik case. I do not disguise that fact. I have said before that I believed that the pendulum had swung too far and that it was necessary in the wake of the Wik decision to make a number of changes.

In proposing those changes, the government is not in any way suggesting that the principles of native title established by the Mabo case should be interfered with or overturned. It is worth reminding the House that the Wik decision did disappoint the expectations of many. It did run contrary to the majority view of the community after the Native Title Act was passed in 1993. The government has not opted for the blanket extinguishment route because, in our view, blanket extinguishment would involve unnecessarily expensive and protracted litigation. It could be exposed to constitutional challenge and it would in symbolic terms also be seen as a far greater affront to what the indigenous people of Australia had achieved in the native title area than other approaches.

It is true that the 10‐point plan does deliver great certainty to the pastoralists and the miners of Australia. And I do not think we should be reluctant to say that, because pastoralists and miners, along with native titleholders, have rights and have interests and it is a question of achieving a fair balance. I believe that the 10‐point plan that the government has enunciated does achieve that fair and appropriate balance. That is why it is being pursued and will continue to be pursued, in the face of opposition from both sides, as a fair and equitable outcome to a very, very difficult problem.

The other area that has been under notice is the report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission into the removal of indigenous children from their families. This report, which was tabled yesterday, has understandably gone very deeply to the emotions of many people in the Australian community. I said yesterday, and I very happily repeat in this parliament today, that personally I feel a very deep sorrow for indigenous people who suffered under the injustices of policies pursued by past generations. I think all members of the House can understand the pain and trauma that many of the people who were affected by those practices might continue to suffer. Rather than reducing the quality of a nation, I think it enhances the quality of a nation for all of us to recognise that people affected by such policies did suffer pain, did suffer injustice, do continue to be affected by it and have had their lives affected by it in a very significant way.

The government has indicated in the submission that it made to the royal commission that it did not believe that financial compensation was appropriate. That is an issue that will be dealt with in more detail when the comprehensive response of the government is brought forward to this parliament. I said also at the reconciliation convention yesterday that I did not believe that current generations of Australians could be held accountable for or be regarded as guilty for the acts of earlier generations over which they had no control.

I do not believe that, as a community, we can ignore history. We must openly acknowledge the injustices of the past. As an intensely proud Australian, along, I am sure, with all other Australians who have a balanced view of the history of this country, I am immensely proud of what we have achieved over the last 200 years. I believe that the Australian achievement is something of which all of us should be proud. It has been a heroic achievement in the face of immense difficulties.

That does not gainsay the fact that there have been significant blemishes. Undoubtedly, the most significant blemish of all in the history of this country over the last 200 years has been the treatment of our indigenous people. I would have thought that was an unarguable fact. I would have thought it was a concept that all of us could embrace, but I would have thought that we could have embraced it without developing an approach to reconciliation that looks backwards rather than forward.

I believe that the proper basis of reconciliation is to recognise the truth about the past, to remain proud about what this country has achieved during the years of its existence, and to resolve, united together as Australians, to work towards a better and more cooperative future. The most effective way of doing that and the most effective way in which we can honour the passage of the 1967 referendum and the wisdom of the Australian people expressed with that referendum is to commit our energy, our resources and our time to remedying those areas of continuing disadvantage amongst the most disadvantaged group within our community—the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

They will recognise, as was made abundantly clear by the political leaders at the time—and I will say a little more about that—that the referendum was passed with an intent that the power conferred on the Commonwealth in regard to Aboriginal policies should be used only for the benefit of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. They will recognise the continuing need for the legislative and other powers of the Commonwealth to be used to redress the profound economic and social disadvantage continuing to be suffered by indigenous Australians, not only those through the health, housing, education, employment and related measures but also through measures to redress, to the extent now possible, the deprivation of life, liberty, property and dignity which indigenous people have suffered through so much of our history.

They will recognise the critical importance to indigenous Australians and the wider Australian community of a continuing reconciliation process based on an understanding of, and frank apologies for, what has gone wrong in the past and total commitment to equal respect in the future. These amendments call upon all Australian governments and parliaments and all Australians to respect and honour both the letter and the spirit of the 1967 referendum. Finally, these amendments support the request that the plaque symbolically commemorating the 1967 referendum, unveiled today in Melbourne by the Governor-General and Dr Faith Bandler, be appropriately housed within this Parliament House.

BREAK.PARA: That is an unusual thing, I suppose, to tack on a motion like this, but it is made necessary by virtue of the fact that there is a suggestion that the plaque ought to be placed at Old Parliament House. This I cannot fathom. I cannot fathom why that would be the intention of this parliament or the intention of this House. Does that mean that when we come to the centenary of Federation and we decide to create any plaques we will do it down at the Melbourne parliament where we all started off—that we will have a plaque at the Melbourne parliament to tell everybody what we think about the centenary of Federation? Of course any plaques or any commemorations that recognise that point will in fact be placed in this Parliament House and nowhere else.

We do not know what the fate of the Old Parliament House is going to be—whether it is going to be offices, whether it is going to be a museum or whether it is going to be something else. But we do know that the lasting memorials of a political nature and those memorials that will have attention drawn to them will be the memorials placed here. I do not want to dwell on that any further. I want to get more to the substance of these issues.

The Prime Minister said that we ought to focus on the future and that we ought to focus upon, primarily, the physical and educational needs of the Aboriginal people. Of course we must focus on all those things. Of course those issues are central. Of course the educational and health needs of the Aboriginal population are absolutely central to the day-to-day concerns of the government. There is no question about that. We would question whether or not this government's commitment to that has been adequate, but we would not question the principle of it.

There are also symbolic issues. There are also issues which go to the sense in the Aboriginal community of their place in the Australian political system, which issues are critical as well. They are a people of nations who live by symbols. They are a people of nations who live by gestures. They are a people who are actually an extraordinarily forgiving people if the symbols are acknowledged, if the problems are acknowledged. They will allow an issue to pass where they get that recognition because they are a people of the spirit as much as they are a people of physical nature.

These things are therefore worth concentrating on and being concerned with as we sit down to think these issues through. They are not people to be toyed with politically in an Australian domestic context; they have been toyed with for a very long time and they do not deserve that. They are not people of substantial power in the community; they are not people to be feared. They are people to be treasured, and that is something that really ought to be reflected in the resolutions of this parliament.

Where did that referendum come from? That referendum back in 1967 came out of an enormous outpouring of warmth in the com munity for the responsibilities of the federal government, the responsibilities of the national parliament. It was not an invention of the Labor Party. It was not an invention, if you like, of agitators on behalf of the Aboriginal community. It was actually a referendum that came from everybody in politics and its intentions were absolutely clear-cut. Statements made at that time by the leadership of the nation make that absolutely clear. The then Deputy Leader of the Country Party said:
This would give the Commonwealth for the first time power to make special laws for the benefit of the Aboriginal people throughout Australia.

It is from that statement that this motion of the government retreats. It was an absolutely clear-cut intention of the government of the day, espoused not by some people who would be associated with the so-called wet faction of the Liberal Party. The then Deputy Leader of the Country Party said that, as far as he was concerned, the purpose of the referendum was to give power to the Commonwealth to make special laws for the benefit of Aboriginal people throughout Australia.

There were worthy campaigners for that referendum on all sides of politics, as well as some in the Aboriginal community at the time. It followed a gradual build-up before the Australian parliament of issues concerning the Aboriginal people. That included the presentation of that magnificent bark petition associated with the people at Yirrkala and the circumstances in which they found themselves. It included the extraordinary difficulties placed on freedom of Aboriginal movement in our communities. It included a determination on the part of the national parliament that there would be no discrimination experienced by Aboriginal people from that point on. It followed a sorry record in relation to protection of Aboriginal liberties during the very substantial portion of our history since Federation.

That position and those views and concerns were supported by all sections of the Australian community. Ninety per cent of them voted for that referendum. Take a look at the history of federal referenda and find another one that got 90 per cent support. It was an extraordinary outpouring of concern by the people of Australia to benefit the Aboriginal community. That was what they determined—to benefit the Aboriginal community. That is the structure of law which still underpins every decision this parliament takes when it makes legislation in regard to the Aboriginal people.

Of course, subsequently that position was augmented. History did not stand still over that 30 years. In many ways, the hopes of the people who campaigned for that referendum have been realised. The situation we confront now is not one of total negativity. It is one of very great difficulty in the atmosphere of race relations in this country. There is no question about that, but by no means does the subsequent 30 years of history since that point of time paint a totally negative picture.

The Racial Discrimination Act passed through the parliament with the support of all sides. That augmented what was done and was thoroughly in keeping with the requirement on the Commonwealth to legislate for the benefit of Aboriginal people. Various land rights acts were associated with that. The Native Title Act also passed through this place. When talking about the difference between the tangible and intangible, it has to be said that every one of these, whilst having their tangible elements, is replete with symbolism. They are so treated by the Aboriginal people as they look to this parliament and seek to draw sustenance from the attitudes and activities of the Commonwealth government.

Another thing has changed dramatically since that time. Whilst there were noted Aboriginal leaders such as Charles Perkins in 1967, if I gave a rollcall of the people who were actually out there advocating the Aboriginal position it would be an honoured list of names but would contain not many Aboriginals. Not very many Aboriginals would be amongst those names. Faith Bandler would be one, and that was part of the symbolism of her role in the unveiling of th plaque.

You can now go down a list as long as your arm of people taking a dignified stand in favour of their people, addressing the rest of the Australian community on their behalf—Pat Dodson, Noel Pearson, Lois O'Donoghue, Gatjil Djerrkura, Marcia Langton, Colleen Hayward, Mick Dodson, Mal Meninga, Mandawuy Yunupingu, Peter Yu, Galurrwuy Yunupingu, Wenten Rubuntja and Tracker Tilmouth. There is a whole raft of them—and that list is not meant to be exclusive, lest someone sneak up behind me and point out that I have left people off that list. The point is that many of those are household names. Many of them are better known to the Australian community than most of us who sit here in the place.

That is an enormously important change. Why did that change come about? It came about essentially because the 1967 referendum was a recognition of political rights and status: `You now speak for yourselves. You have a parliament to address. It is the Commonwealth parliament. You address that parliament when you have grievances, when you need to deal with the issues that affect the nation.' That is what was said in 1967. In a sense, it was a charge to the Aboriginal people by the Australian community: `Address us now. We have kept you out of political expression for a very long time. Address us now.' Of course, they have done that since that point of time and they have made quite clear the issues and concerns they have.

Those concerns are being picked up to some extent and we are dealing with those issues in this parliament today. We will deal with them again in relation to the stolen children. We will deal with them also when we come to considering the 10 points in relation to the Native Title Act. One thing I am looking forward to when that legislation comes into this place is an understanding of what the 10 points actually mean. An awful lot of people in the community have a lot of confidence about what those 10 points mean. I am not one of them, I must confess.

I can see you slotting in an interpretation on each one of those points in any particular direction you choose to go. I rather think I will see Tim Fischer come out one day and say, `There's bucket loads of extinguishment in this,' and then somebody else will address the Aboriginal community with, `All your rights are protected.' We are left to puzzle as to who is telling what, about whom, in what circumstances and when. We are entitled to be a little quizzical about that. And I suppose we will find out all about that when that particular act is tabled.

But we do know—and the government knows it, because the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) made this amply clear in his public advice to parliament before the Wik decision was handed down—if residual native title is found on pastoral leases, any attempt to extinguish that will run up against, firstly, a lack of power on the part of the Commonwealth to do so and, secondly, if the attempt is made, massive substantial compensation. Those are not my words but those of the Attorney-General in the explanatory notes that he put out to the legislation which subsequently was withdrawn to be amended in the context of Wik.

The government knows what its responsibilities are and it knows the limitations on its powers. It understands that. There is no doubt in my mind that, whatever actually emerges in the legislation, there is a thoroughgoing understanding in the government's mind of how far they can go and, if they do transgress, what uncertainty will be created for the pastoralists—and certainty will be created for the Australian taxpayers if they find themselves with a piece of legislation which is likely to be successfully challenged with massive compensation resulting from it.

I do know this: whatever there is in the legislation, whatever might have been said to any particular group in the Australian community, the Australian government does understand what the limitations upon it are; and if it acts against them, it does so knowingly. But these will be tremendously important concerns of this parliament: the way we address both that legislation and the question of the stolen children.

My time is almost up, but we will have another opportunity to debate those issues in this place. We will have an opportunity to make restitution. We will have an opportunity to state generously what we believe about the nature of race relations in this country. We will have an opportunity in that regard to make the national apology that needs to be made at that point of time for the suffering of those people who have experienced such an extraordinary deprivation as a result of quite recent government decisions, both state and federal. We will have a chance for a bit of an outpouring of emotion in this parliament in a way in which there ought to be at that point of time.

But let us now with this motion honour the people who passed the 1967 referendum—90 per cent of the Australian people. Let us honour them. Let us honour also the people who put forward that referendum; let us honour the Aboriginal people with the passing of an appropriate resolution in this place, and not a half‐hearted one.
