TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on this very important matter of Aboriginal reconciliation. A major step forward for the nation occurred on 27 May 1967 with the long overdue granting of full citizenship rights to indigenous people. It had been evolving for some time and had included developments that took place during the Menzies prime ministership. Indeed, it is a source of some pride on my own part that it was a relation of mine who in many ways spearheaded that campaign—one Jessie Street.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons that it took a long time to evolve was that there were elements in our community who continued to espouse divisive and in some cases racist views, and held at bay those who had a more kindly and more rational outlook on these matters. But when, to gauge the true feelings of the Australian people, a referendum was held—as has been pointed out in this place, in fact, over the last few minutes—it emerged that there was overwhelming support, in fact in the order of 90 per cent, for the full citizenship rights for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

It is timely, 30 years on, to reflect upon that decision; to analyse the attitudinal and social changes that have occurred during that period; to measure where things are now; and, most importantly, to chart a positive course of action for the future. Interestingly, I believe that the attitudes of the Australian people have not changed very much over those years in this area. There is still the same level of real support for the rights and welfare of indigenous people, and there is still the same strong level of commitment for equality of opportunity. As Australians, we do indeed share a commitment for a fair go for everyone.

We are increasingly, I think, aware of, interested in and proud of the culture and heritage of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. As a unified Australian community, we must seek to rise above those who talk endlessly about the problems, without attempting to find solutions. I for one would not pretend that there are easy solutions.

But I would say that one of the first steps is for people to adopt a more visibly tolerant attitude and commitment to, if you like, becoming personally more involved in improving the situation. I do not know whether this is right, but I recently heard that some 80 per cent of Australians have never actually personally spoken to an Aboriginal.

BREAK.PARA: Indeed, in my own case, I found it very interesting recently to spend a night with the rural leadership training program, which is an outstanding course for young Australians, men and women, involved in leadership in rural Australia. These particular courses—and there have been four of them now—begin with an intensive few days in the Kimberleys where people camp out and hike along difficult route marches and what have you during the days; it is pretty character building stuff.

Having spent a day and an evening with the last intake, I found it very interesting to discover that they had learnt an enormous amount from the Aboriginal participant on the course and from the Aboriginal guide on the course who had shown them a lot of the things that were of significance to him and his people in that outback setting. In fact, there was a fellow in his mid‐thirties from my electorate who, when I arrived on the scene, wanted to tell me that—and he said this in front of the Aboriginal participant and the Aboriginal guide—he had arrived on the course as a bigot and was leaving as somebody who was no longer a bigot. He had found that opportunity to interact and to work alongside—even survive alongside—Aboriginal people in an environment with which they are more familiar with than we are. It was a very interesting, illuminating and moving experience.

To restore the dignity and self-worth of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait islander people will require goodwill from all Australians, a spirit of cooperation, a determination to take this nation forward as a unified country which respects individual differences. We need to ensure that there is a warm spread of goodwill rather than the fuelling of ugly fires of discontent. We need respect for human dignity and the right of all people to be treated fairly.

While I firmly believe that the great majority of citizens want that equality, to achieve it will still require a conscious change in the hearts, minds and actions of some Australians. We need to demonstrate that good old Australian spirit of pitching in and helping in a constructive manner. The solutions start with individuals and what they are prepared to do personally, especially in those urban settings in our country towns and in our major cities where some 90 per cent of modern indigenous people live. But there is an important role for government—and others have discussed this today—to provide the framework, the resources and, in some cases, the inspiration for positive change.

I want to limit myself to some remarks about activities in my own portfolio. I am taking a number of measures to attain a greater level of involvement and participation by indigenous people. For example, I have supported the establishment of a team of Aboriginal landcare facilitators to assist in sustainable land management activity. Many people feel that, with their affinity for the land, the Aboriginal people have a special role to play there. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are currently responsible for the management of some 16 per cent of Australia's land surface and comprise a significant percentage of the population of rural and regional communities.

I have also provided support for the establishment of a pilot market garden project in Gilgandra to enable young Aboriginal people to learn the necessary horticultural skills to grow vegetables and native foods. I am providing joint support with the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) in a pilot youth suicide prevention project for indigenous people in the Northern Territory, details of which will be announced at a later date.

I believe that there are many opportunities as a government to establish meaningful programs of worthwhile activities which will help give young people a sense of self‐esteem as well as a sense of pride and purpose. I believe it is absolutely essential that we assist indigenous people to become economically empowered to move towards greater self-reliance and self-sufficiency, particularly in rural and regional areas.

Next week, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron) and I will be jointly announcing a rural industry strategy which will help address the socioeconomic and environmental issues which impact on the development and sustainability of indigenous industries and enterprises.

Having made those few brief remarks about where I think there has perhaps been a lack of focus on where real improvements in relationships in our communities can be achieved—that is, at the level of the local community—I give my personal commitment to continue with efforts to further create opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

I represent a large rural electorate. It has the fifth highest number of indigenous people of any electorate represented in this House. I understand the problems that we face in developing better outcomes and more harmonious relationships within and between rural communities in this area of concern, where in the final analysis real improvements in relationships must take place.

There are no easy answers. There are no easy solutions. In fairness to governments of all persuasions, if there had been, we would have found more of them. I seek to reaffirm my support and my party's support for the strongest efforts to be made to create a better future for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Gareth, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The passage of the 1967 referendum 30 years ago today was a defining moment in modern Australian history. It was certainly a defining moment for my generation. There was not much in the 1960s—the Vietnam War decade—that gave much hope to those of us coming of age then that the world was becoming a saner, more decent, more civilised place.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the referendum campaign, with its cross‐party support, its massive affirmative outcome and the spirit that then prevailed that we were all doing something good and decent and overdue to recognise the humanity of our fellow indigenous Australians, did give us a beacon of hope about the future.

The campaign, as it took place up and down the country, brought many Australians face to face with Aboriginal Australians for the first time and began, in many instances, that crucial process of stripping away the layer of gauze through which so many white Australians looked at their black neighbours and through which so many now still unhappily look at their Asian neighbours. Unless we start looking at each other as individual human beings, with individual human strengths and weaknesses, not as types or categories or stereotypes, we are never going to make much progress with reconciliation or, for that matter, engagement in the Asian region.

The referendum in 1967 gave hope to everyone in the country who cared about the plight of Aboriginal people, their dispossession, their annihilation in many instances, certainly their humiliation, their forced assimilation, their living conditions, the prejudice and the discrimination still existing against them, and their psychological despair. It gave everyone who despaired that the state governments of the day would ever do the right thing in response to all those hurts and humiliations a stimulus to start thinking, talking and planning about what the Commonwealth could now do on behalf of the whole nation. It made every Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander person in this country stand up tall and proud and confident, as they had never been entitled to before, that the future would be different. But would the future be different?

Let me tell the House the story of just one black Australian whom I came to know very closely a few years after the referendum, because it is a story about that hope. It is also a story about the reality of the Aboriginal experience in this country as it was after the referendum and, frankly, as it continues to this day.

The young man's name was Brian Kamara Willis. He was born early in the 1950s somewhere in the Northern Territory—he never knew quite where—of an Aboriginal mother and a white father. He was, as the full bloods called him and as he called himself, a `yella fella'. That in-between status haunted him all his life. He was, like so many of his generation and the generations before him, a stolen child. As a very young kid, he was snatched from the arms of his mother, taken to Adel aide to a childhood of institutions and foster homes, to an environment in which—for reasons that ought to be very understandable if we stop for a moment to think about them—he really never settled down.

But in his mid‐teens the 1967 referendum was passed and, encouraged and stimulated by it, he went back to the Northern Territory, proud now of his Aboriginality, to try to rediscover his roots. When he did discover them he was shattered. He found his mother living out a desperately unhappy existence in fringe dwellers camps around Darwin. I cannot begin to describe the emotion with which Brian described to me the exhilaration of first finding his mother, and then the despair at the circumstances in which he found her.

He was a very bright and personable kid, but this knocked the stuffing out of him. He drifted into labouring and rouseabout, knockabout jobs around the towns and the bush in the territory, and he seemed to be eventually heading down a similar path. That was, at least, until in the early 1970s—with the Commonwealth, especially with the new government in 1972 now devoting major resources to Aboriginal policies and programs—he actually picked up a job as a field officer for the new Aboriginal Legal Service in Alice Springs, funded by the Commonwealth under its referendum powers.

He blossomed in a dozen different ways. His potential was recognised and it was nurtured by those around him, and he formed what would have before then seemed an absolutely unachievable and unreachable objective—the idea of himself becoming a lawyer. With the help of Aboriginal study grants he came to Melbourne to do his final year's school as university preparation. That is where I and my family came to know him, and we became very close friends.

A year or so later he was admitted to Melbourne University Law School, where I was then teaching, under a Commonwealth—again, post‐referendum—disadvantaged students quota. And things for a while went very well. But eventually he began to be oppressed by the environment pressing in around him. Partly, it was physical—he and his young family felt hemmed in by the city and longed for space; they were desperate to get out into a countryside without fences where he could feel again some attachment, some relationship, to the land. It was with this young man that I think I first really actually understood how much the land mattered to Aboriginal people: the sense of belonging, the spiritual attachment, the sense of despair at the dispossession.

The psychological pressure was also getting him down. Despite the change of atmosphere that was associated with the referendum, he and his family were still experiencing put‐downs and humiliation. There was a constant sense that he did not really belong. He had to be constantly proving more about himself, about his abilities and about his character than anyone else had to. So, in the event, he deferred the completion of his degree and went back to the Northern Territory.

His talents and his new education were such that he in fact became, in quite a short time, the Director of the Aboriginal Legal Service. He became an outspoken champion of his people in Central Australia, speaking and writing about a whole range of policy issues—and, in particular, speaking and writing in very fierce and moving terms about the lost souls of the stolen children. In a newspaper article in 1980 he spoke of his fellow victims in these terms:
They had no sense of where they could call their home, no sense of being wanted, all traces of their families had disappeared.
I must say that every human being has to have these basic elements: A sense of belonging to someone, some identifiable area you can call home.
Once you have got these essential things you know that love is there. They make life for a human being worth living.

So Brian Kamara Willis's life until then, although it had had its awful moments, was one of extraordinary achievement and brilliant promise, and nearly all of it was made possible by the 1967 referendum and by what followed from it.

But the story does not have a happy ending. In the end, Brian Kamara Willis just could not fight the pressures, shrug off the prejudic es and sustain the struggle for long enough. One night in March 1980 he went to a political gathering—as he often did—and the people there remembered him getting very distressed at one stage during the evening and saying something like, `The urban black, the part‐Aboriginal, is the man in between. He has nothing.' He went home and, at the age of 26 or 27, in front of his wife and his two young children, he took up a shotgun and blew out his brains.

I spoke of all of this, about the destruction of a brilliant young life, in the Senate back in 1980 when it all happened. The memory of that young man and his family and what happened to them haunts me still.

The truth of the matter, Mr Deputy Speaker, is that for all the hopes that were raised by the 1967 referendum, all that has happened since, for all the years that have passed since, things are now not so very different. There are still justices unredressed and young lives being tragically wasted, and there is still a lack of understanding—by too many people in too many decision‐making positions in this country—of the nature of the problem and what needs to be done.

How can we still be arguing now, in 1997, as we are today, whether the referendum was really designed to benefit Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people? Does the government really want to stand up now and say that the referendum was to allow the passage of legislation to hurt and discriminate against our Aboriginal people?

How can we still be arguing now in 1997 about the need to focus not just on the so‐called practical measures—important as they are—and not as well on the means to address to the extent now possible the deprivation of life and liberty and property and dignity which so many indigenous people have suffered through so much of our nation's history?

How can we still be arguing now, as we are today with this motion, whether or not we, as a parliament and as a nation, should apologise for what went wrong in the past? Mr Deputy Speaker, that we are arguing about these things on this commemoration day 30 years after the referendum shows just how far we still have to go as a nation in recognising the reality of life as it still now is for so many of our indigenous people.

It shows how important it is on this day that we pass a motion in this parliament—amended in the way that we propose—which looks both backward to the hurts of the past and the achievements of 1967 in addressing them, and forward to what remains to be done; which states very clearly everything that has to be done and the Commonwealth's responsibility in doing it; which expresses some genuine affection and understanding about the humanity of our fellow indigenous Australians and some understanding of the enormity of the wrongs done to them; and which is expressed, Mr Deputy Speaker, in terms which all of us can not only endorse, but of which we can be proud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALKER.NAME: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty years ago today, two referenda proposals were put to the Australian people. The first was to break the nexus between the numbers in the House of Representatives and the Senate. That proposal was defeated. The second contained two proposals: one relating to section 51 of the constitution and the other relating to section 127. Section 51 of the constitution prevented the Commonwealth from making a law for the benefit of Aboriginal people. Section 127 related to the counting of people and said that Aboriginal people should not be included. Of themselves, they were not remarkable.

SPEECH.PARA: If you look back to the original framing of the constitution, to the four debates in 1890, 1891, 1897 and 1898, it is extraordinary that when section 51 of the constitution was debated, on not a single occasion were Aboriginal people mentioned. When section 127 was debated, on only a few occasions were Aboriginal people mentioned.

Events develop their own mythology but, in spite of the first referendum proposal being defeated, these two were passed with the highest majority in the country's history. In my own state of Victoria, it was 95 per cent; in the state with the least support, Western Australia, it was still 80 per cent. The Elec toral Commission did not send out a no case; they only sent out a yes case. When asked why, they replied, `We've yet to learn of any opposition to the Aboriginal proposal that exists from any quarter.'
So why are we here talking about it 30 years later? Perhaps it has more to do with the comments made at the time by Faith Bandler, whose name appears in this motion. Her comments were:

For Aborigines, an overwhelming yes vote can mean a new life of hope. When you write yes in the lower square of your ballot paper, you are holding out the hand of friendship and wiping out 200 years of injustice and inhumanity.
She continued:
Only the federal government has the money and so by voting yes you give the responsibility to the national parliament and make possible a program of real equal rights and equal opportunity.

What 1967 was about was hope. There is a great deal of feeling and an enormous range of opinions across this parliament and across the Australian community. I cannot pretend to have known anything about Aboriginal affairs prior to March 1990 when I was asked to be shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs. Within half an hour of being offered that appointment, I got a phone call from Fred Chaney, who was, and remains, a friend. He said to me, `Congratulations. It's a wonderful job. It will change you.' There is no doubt that having to confront such great poverty and such great injustice, for someone like me, over the next three years, did change me. But it is an experience that not many Australians have and, in the end, different Australians hold different views through the different experiences they have had and the different degree to which they have had to approach or confront the issues.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) talked about symbolism. I can put another item of symbolism. It was in 1990, when we discussed the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill, when I stood on the other side of the chamber and the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs stood where I am and, at the end of a very difficult nine‐month debate, we leaned across this table and shook hands—the only time in this House that that has happened. We shook hands because we had been able to come to a joint position. It was not easy, but the parliament spoke with one voice.

The Leader of the Opposition talked about honouring the people of 1967. We would honour them much more if we had the capacity in this place not to be as divided as we are today, but to actually speak with one voice. This debate makes me incredibly sad because to me the message of 1967 was that real change can be achieved if the country or the parliament works for a common position. Clearly, the opposition believes there is a high moral ground to be obtained by not seeking that common position. I believe their views to be genuine but, nonetheless, it causes me immense sadness.

Thirty years ago, this country faced far more than a referendum. It faced far more than simply putting Aboriginal people on the census. It faced the question of whether the Commonwealth would have the constitutional responsibility to make laws for Aboriginal people and, in doing so, gave Aboriginal people a place in society. The voices of the likes of Charles Perkins and Faith Bandler showed, for the first time, Aboriginal people taking a key voice in the future that faced them. That referendum was about hope, about whether health, education and job prospects would in any way be better in the future than they were at the time. Today, I am ashamed to say that the hopes of many of those people who voted in the 1967 referendum are dashed.

There are good things happening in Aboriginal affairs. In 1972, there were only 75 Aborigines in higher education; today there are 7,000. In 1972, the rate of childhood mortality in Aboriginal kids was 10 times that of the general population; today in the Northern Territory, it is three times—a dramatic change, but still a long way to go. Yet there are still a strident few who say that Aboriginal people are the beneficiaries of reverse racism; who would say Aborigines enjoy privileges over other Australians. That view appals me.

The difference with Aboriginal people is they have suffered systematic discrimination at the hands of government. Had I been an Aboriginal kid born of a half‐caste mother in New South Wales in 1956 I probably would not have attended primary school because of statutes passed by the state government. Until the early 1960s Aboriginal people could not marry or own a bank account in the Northern Territory without permission. Until 1968 Aboriginal children were still being forcibly removed from their parents in Western Australia. Until the early 1970s Aboriginal people in Queensland had their movements restricted and needed what was effectively a passport to leave a reserve.

I have given a talk on legal discrimination against Aboriginal people on a number of occasions and on each occasion I have had the same thing happen. There is a small group of people waiting to see me as I leave and they say, `We are from South Africa and we never did all those things.' But that is what can happen when there is such a minority that is hidden from most of the country.

It is very easy, with hindsight, to say things were wrong. It is very easy to talk of words. Clearly what happened to the children who were removed from their families was wrong—deeply, horribly, morally wrong. Taking children away from their parents is wrong. Placing them in institutions, denying them the truth about their past and denying them access to information about their parents, is wrong—deeply, horribly, morally wrong. But we say that from the perspective of today.

One of the people who administered that policy was Paul Hasluck, a man whom I admire immensely. Before he died I had the opportunity to discuss it with him. Of course, at the time, it was done with the best intentions. It was done by people like Paul Hasluck who were actually trying to do something at a time when the majority of Australians did not give a damn, when the view was that the Aboriginal people were still going to die out as a race. It was done by thousands of decent Christian people who took Aboriginal kids into their home thinking they were giving them something better for the future. No‐one could imagine the consequences that would follow.

BREAK.PARA: Of course it not only struck at the core of Aboriginal communities, in the end it diminished all Australians. The debate of recent times has led to quite an outpouring of emotion around the country. The letters pages of the newspapers show this very clearly. There was a letter that moved me immensely in the Age over the weekend; the story of a crying policeman. The person was talking of his father who was the duty policeman at Echuca from 1922 to 1946. His father would often come home and cry, sobbing like a child, sitting at the front of the house. When his son asked him what the problem was, his father said he would tell him when he grew up.

The letter said that on a camping trip, when this kid was 16, he asked his father if he would tell him the reason he cried. His father told him that when he went out on duty on those mornings his sergeant would order him to accompany two welfare officers to the Aboriginal mission station to give them bodily protection when they entered nice, clean simple homes of half‐caste people and bodily removed nine‐, 10‐, 11‐ and 12‐year‐old children from their loving mothers and fathers to commandeered taxis. They were taken away to the far reaches of New South Wales and Queensland. They were farmed out to the service of wealthy businessmen and graziers. No doubt a few were treated well. That was the reason his father cried on those days.

In the end those acts diminish us all. It should not have happened. It obviously must never happen again. But I have had the perspective to think and talk and care about this for seven years and I have decided words are cheap. We can pass motions. We can have all good intentions. But if you actually look today in my area of health, there is no evidence of any improvement whatsoever in the last decade. In fact, in many areas things have gone backwards, or they have remained static for the Aboriginal population where things have improved for the rest of the population. So the gap has actually widened.

Words are cheap. Motions are cheap. What is required is a generosity of spirit. The message from the 1967 referendum is that things can be achieved with bipartisanship. I will not debate one by one the amendments put up by the Labor Party. I will merely point out that the Native Title Act of 1993 clearly had elements in it that were to the detriment of Aboriginal people, such as making available extinguishment of native title under certain conditions; allowing compulsory acquisition and validation of past acts that were made invalid because of native title. What we are facing with the Wik decision is no different.

I do not want my successor as health minister to stand here in 30 years time and say to Australians that the original Australians still suffer disadvantage in health, education and employment. The changes are not going to come about through motions. They are not going to come about through words. They are going to come about through governments having the generosity of spirit to allow Aboriginal people to make their own mistakes. They are going to come about by taking a clear focus on the future, not a focus on the past. They are going to come about by us being able to achieve things that are achievable, not promising the unachievable. I do not want more words. I do not have more time for the past. But I do, very much, want a new direction for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The wording of this motion has already been subject to some controversy and I will address individually each of the five points made in it. Before I do I want to make it clear that, though I think this motion represents a series of symbolic political platitudes that do not make a lot of real difference to the plight of Aboriginal people, they do not help reconciliation at all. I am determined that the Labor Party should not prevail by preparing an even more useless motion—mouthing all the things that they think are politically correct and that privileged social elites want to hear—that totally ignores that for the last 13 years Labor was in control. They had the power to do something and failed. Things have actually gotten worse. Because of these things I propose to modify this motion in accordance with the amendment circulated in my name. I move:

BREAK.PARA: That all words after "paragraphs" (first occurring) be omitted with a view to substituting the following:
"(2), (3), (4) and (5) and substitute the following paragraphs:
(2) reaffirms support for the spirit of that referendum, which received the support of 90.77 percent of the Australian people;
(3) recognises that the Commonwealth's legislative and other powers should be used to address the economic and social disadvantages suffered by Australians of any background on the basis of need;
(4) emphasises the value of a cooperative effort to build a better future for all Australians, regardless of race, creed or colour; and

(5) supports the request that the plaque symbolically commemorating the 1967 referendum, unveiled today in Melbourne by the Governor General and Dr Faith Bandler at the Australian Reconciliation Convention, be appropriately housed within Old Parliament House".

The first point of the original motion recognises that this is the 30th anniversary of the referendum that changed the constitution and gave the Commonwealth the power to make special laws. This referendum took place in an environment where Aboriginal people were not recognised as people and suffered terribly from illness, disease and neglect.

The referendum put to the people addressed two things: it enabled Aboriginal people to be counted in reckoning Australia's population, and it gave the Commonwealth government the power to make laws for Aboriginal people in the states, concurrently with state governments. I do not think that any person in this country would not recognise that these were important and necessary things that needed to be done. We wanted to bring the Aboriginal people on board as equals. The problem is not with this but rather with what has actually happened since.

The second point in the original motion reaffirms the support for the outcome of the referendum, which was overwhelmingly supported by the people. But I do not think that people in Australia should be happy with the situation for some Aborigines in Australia today. Rather, we should be looking at what went wrong.

In reality, we gave the Commonwealth powers to do things through a referendum, and it failed. I have been accused of being a racist and hating Aborigines. Neither of these things are true. The real racist act in Australia has been to pretend that things were going to change by amending the constitution and then letting them get worse. But things are not worse for everyone.

I have been accused of saying that Aborigines are not disadvantaged. That is clearly nonsense. Some Aborigines are extremely disadvantaged and need help, but there are some others doing very well. Despite this, all Aborigines are treated the same in many aspects of Commonwealth support and legislation. Why do we persist? This approach has failed. Australians, whether Aboriginal or not, know this is true. We must change the way we do things before things can get better. In view of this, I wish to amend this portion of the motion to read that we reaffirm the spirit of the outcome of the referendum.

The third point of this motion asks us to recognise the need for legislative and other powers of the Commonwealth to deal separately with problems facing Aborigines as if they live in a vacuum. This is wrong. It is a recipe for more of the same failed policies. Governments have interpreted the results of the 1967 referendum to mean that we should separate Aborigines from mainstream Australia in order to solve the problem that they face. We have been travelling down that road for 30 years and invested billions of dollars to find that many of the measures used to rate our performance show that we have made it worse.

By deliberately isolating one group of Australians from the mainstream, governments have increased the difficulty that they will face in overcoming the long-term problems that are before them. Many people in this country want a change in direction. We need to overcome the problems faced by all minority groups in Australia, but the biggest facing us relate to Aborigines.

I look around me in this chamber at so many of the members who have accused me of being a racist because I have questioned the approach taken by this and previous governments to Aborigines in this country. I am struck by the thought that the real problem can be found amongst the people who have sat in this place year after year since 1967 and achieved so little. They have thrown money at the problem in the hope that it will go away, and we have seen precious little for that.

In order to solve any problem, those facing it must be involved in the solution. You cannot do that if you give them power on one hand and take away responsibility for the outcomes with the other. For too long ATSIC has been a power unto itself and the programs it delivered unaccounted for. Enormous amounts of money have been spent without true accountability. There has been no looking at outcomes to make sure that failure was not repeated. Many Australians feel cheated by the money wasted over the years by ATSIC, and I understand this frustration. ATSIC has failed as a product of Commonwealth legislation and needs to be abolished.

Indigenous Australians need to be brought back into the mainstream so that their problems can be dealt with on a needs basis. They should be protected from bureaucratic failure to the same extent that other Australians are. The social security, health and employment services in this country are far from perfect, but they offer better services integrated into the rest of the community than ATSIC. Their outcomes are far more accountable.

We cannot afford to continue down a path that costs such a fortune to achieve so little. This is why I want to amend the original motion to have all people, including Aborigines, helped on a basis of need. Aborigines will not be worse off because of this. They will actually get the improvement that they thought would come from the 1967 referendum.

The fourth part of the original motion acknowledges that some terrible things were done in the past and I, like many Australians, am sorry for the fact that they occurred. This does not mean, however, that I am in some way responsible for what has happened, and I resent being made to feel guilty for something I did not do. What I want to be responsible for, however, is fixing the way we deal with Aboriginal issues today.

We cannot and must not foster or champion Aboriginal culture as an alternative society to our own. We must all be Australians together if this country is to have any chance of a prosperous and harmonious future. I want a cooperative effort to build a better future for all Australians, regardless of race, creed or colour. I commend my amendment to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worth noting that, when the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) moved his motion, only nine ministers were present in the House and less than half the backbench. Immediately after the Prime Minister finished his speech, he left the chamber and did not show the courtesy of remaining throughout the debate. This is an important motion. I think that is indicative of why the opposition is moving an amendment to the Prime Minister's motion. It does not go far enough. His heart is not in it. The words are mouthed, but the heart is not in it.

SPEECH.PARA: In his speech, the Prime Minister says the motivation for the 1967 referendum was for the benefit of the Aboriginal race. The Prime Minister says that the spirit of the 1967 referendum was to remedy disadvantage. Yet the basis of the 10-point plan, the basis of the response to Wik, is disadvantage to the Aboriginal race. It discriminates against the Aboriginal race. That is why the Prime Minister's 10-point plan is wrong. That is why the Prime Minister's 10-point plan is vulnerable to a successful constitutional challenge.

The 1967 referendum changed the race power for all time. When the 1967 referendum bill went through the parliament, the intent, the purpose, of the bill when it was put to the people was one of a beneficial power for the advantage of the Aboriginal race. There was no `no case'. The Prime Minister Harold Holt said in his second reading speech:

If the proposals relating to Aboriginals are approved by the people, the Government would regard it as desirable to hold discussions with the States to secure the widest measure of agreement with respect to Aboriginal advancement.
The then Leader of the Opposition, Gough Whitlam, said:

The fact is that with the excision of the words from paragraph (xxvi) of section 51 the members of this Parliament will be able for the first time to do something for Aboriginals—Aboriginals representing the greatest pockets of poverty and disease in this country.

One of the advantages of repealing the paragraph (xxvi) words will be that the Commonwealth will be able to assist those very extensive States—the three largest States in Australia—which have not the financial resources to deal with this problem. The Commonwealth can at least bring the resources of the whole nation to bear in favour of the Aboriginals where they live.
Mr Wentworth, the member for Mackellar, said:

Some people say—I think wrongly—that no discrimination is necessary in regard to the Aboriginal people. I think that some discrimination is necessary. But I think it should be favourable, not unfavourable.

I believe that these people need some discriminatory legislation which is in their favour. It is not right to say to these people: `We will treat you as we would treat any other Australian'. To do this would submerge and destroy their culture.
Mr Bryant, the member for Wills, said:
Then we as a Parliament and as individual members must take up the challenge on behalf of the Aboriginal people and recover the last 180 years.
In the House of Representatives, Mr Beazley Snr, the member for Fremantle, said:
The Commonwealth should have this power because it is the Government which is confronted with the conscience of the world on this issue.
In the Senate, Senator Murphy said:
In this proposed law there is no suggestion of any intended discrimination in respect of Aboriginals except a discrimination in their favour.
Yet this government will not accept the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley). Paragraph (3) of the amendment says:

recognises, as was made abundantly clear by the political leaders of the time, that the referendum was passed with the intent that the power conferred on the Commonwealth only be used for the benefit of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people;
When the yes case went to the people, it was a yes case only, not a no case. This is what the case for yes said:

The purposes of these proposed amendments to the Commonwealth Constitution are to remove any ground for the belief that, as at present worded, the Constitution discriminates in some ways against people of the Aboriginal race, and, at the same time, to make it possible for the Commonwealth Parliament to make special laws for the people of the Aboriginal race, wherever they may live, if the Commonwealth Parliament considers this desirable or necessary.
The Commonwealth's object will be to co‐operate with the States to ensure that together we act in the best interests of the Aboriginal people of Australia.

That was what was distributed in the yes case, countersigned by the then Prime Minister, Harold Holt; the Deputy Prime Minister, the Rt Hon. John McEwen; and the Leader of the Opposition, Gough Whitlam.
The leaders also contributed to a journal called Smoke Signals, the official organ of the Aborigines Advancement League of Victoria. The Prime Minister, Harold Holt, said in that journal in May 1967:

We cannot allow it to be said that our Federal Constitution discriminates against some people who live within our shores—the Aborigines. Nor is it, we believe, acceptable to the Australian people as a whole that the National Parliament should not have power to make special laws for the people of the Aboriginal race, where that is in their best interests.
You had the then Leader of the Opposition, Gough Whitlam, saying:
The welfare of Australian Aboriginals requires that this referendum be carried; the good name of Australia demands that it be carried overwhelmingly.
. . . the Commonwealth is accepting greater and greater responsibility; it must now be empowered to accept that responsibility on behalf of Aboriginals, as it already does for all other Australians.
Doug Anthony, a former Deputy Leader of the National Party, whose son now sits in this parliament, said:

. . . words which can be read as discriminating against the Aboriginal race will be removed. This would give the Commonwealth Government, for the first time, power to make special laws for the benefit of the Aboriginal people throughout Australia.

It was a beneficial power. The Prime Minister is not above the law. The government is not above the law. The 10‐point plan will not work. It has got constitutional problems. Today there was a writ lodged in the High Court of Australia challenging a bill that passed through this parliament in the last fortnight and that writ, if it is accepted by the High Court, will present an opportunity for the High Court once and for all to determine the question.

But this Prime Minister, in his speech today, says, `Our native title amendments, the plans we have devised, are a fair and balanced plan.' They are not. They are all detrimental to the Aboriginal race. He concedes it is a significant winding back after the decision in Wik. I agree with that, and that is why the Prime Minister is not on solid constitutional ground. He ignores the spirit and purpose of the 1967 referendum. That is why the government will not accept our amendment.

Another part of our amendment that they will not accept relates to the plaque. The plaque that was unveiled today is a recognition—it is the 30th anniversary—a celebration, of the 1967 referendum. In the Old Parliament House, the bark petition was tabled. It is now housed in the new Parliament House. In the Old Parliament House the Australia Act was passed. It is now housed in the new Parliament House. This plaque commemorating the 30th anniversary should be housed in the new Parliament House. We do not want to go back; we want to go forward. It is a reaffirmation by this parliament. That is why the Prime Minister's words are weasel words. He has got a problem. He is not above the law. He cannot discriminate; nor can his government. That is why the High Court will intervene, as its constitutional authority requires it to do. Its power is to lay down the common law.

Today I had the good fortune to listen to the current Governor‐General, Sir William Deane, who gave an occasional address at the Australian Reconciliation Convention. This is what he—a former justice of the High Court—had to say:

BREAK.PARA: . . . the effect of the exclusion of "the Aboriginal race in any State" in s.51(xxvi) had been, while it remained, to prevent the enactment, under any of the heads of Commonwealth power, of a law which could properly be characterised as a law with respect to the Aboriginal race in any State. That meant that, while the exclusion remained, the Commonwealth lacked legislative power to make any law designed for the special benefit of the Aboriginal people in any of the States. In contrast—
and here is the punch line—
once the exclusion was deleted, the Commonwealth, under s.51(xxvi), possessed plenary legislative power to make any special laws which it deemed necessary for the welfare of the Aboriginal peoples.

That is from the current Governor‐General. And that is why this Prime Minister is behaving like a constitutional vandal. That is why he will not accept our amendments. The debate after Wik was the prejudiced leading the blind. The debate now has been transformed into the blind leading the prejudiced.

I commend the opposition amendments to the parliament. They need to be picked up because they are a reaffirmation of what the parliament and the people intended in the 1967 referendum that was overwhelmingly endorsed by over 90 per cent of the Australian population.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honour able member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the government to address problems facing small business.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is an important time in which this particular MPI has been proposed. It was proposed even prior to the release today of the Yellow Pages Small Business Index. It was proposed because the small business sector has been promised so much by this government, but this government has failed to deliver. This is a government that suffers from weak and indecisive leadership. It is a government which is directionless, and it is also a government where the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) parades himself as the self-styled high priest of small business. He leaves it to his Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) to parade himself as the acolyte that is going to deliver the holy writ, and that holy writ is going to be the salvation of small business.

SPEECH.PARA: Simply, the coalition when in opposition went to the people of this country and said, `Small business is where it is at. Small business is going to be the salvation economically of this country and we are going to deliver in spades.' They released their policy called `A new deal for small business'. Actually, it is a raw deal for small business. What they did was raise expectations and then deliver nothing. They are a government which delivers simply wishy washy rhetoric.

There are a couple of examples that spring immediately to mind. What happened when this minister took over? I accept the fact that in opposition he was the spokesperson on finance and they shuffled him into small business and said, `Geoff, you go and deliver the goods that we promised in the last election campaign.' What did he do? He failed the fund and therefore had shut down the Franchising Code Council—immediately: gone. Franchising is one of the fastest growing areas of small business in this country. It needs protection and it needs codes in place to look after those people who enter into relationships with franchisors. They promised a 50 per cent reduction in the burden of red tape and to eliminate compliance costs. What has been delivered? Exactly the opposite.

Having been elected to government with the overwhelming support of the small business constituency of this country, there was an expectation that there would be something delivered. So what did the government do? They promised that they would have a committee of inquiry into the needs of small business. So the Bell committee was established. The Bell committee was established under the chairmanship of Charlie Bell, the head of the McDonald's organisation in this country, probably the largest franchisor in Australia. He was going to oversee a committee inquiry into the needs of franchisees and other small businesses in this country.

BREAK.PARA: It is interesting, is it not, that immediately after that decision was taken, the Australian Certified Practising Accountants Association came out and said in the Telegraph on 5 May year that this was nothing more than a government of committees. And well it is. The comment made this year could have applied equally last year.

The principal reason for commissioning this report was to reduce compliance costs and red tape. It dodged tax reform and in fact the Prime Minister went out of his way to say that we would not have any tax reform considered as part of that Bell committee inquiry. What did they do? Well, not a great deal. At the end of the day, 62 recommendations were brought down by Mr Bell. His report was called Time for business.

At this stage we then saw the 1996‐97 budget intervene. What did we see small business get out of it? The export market development grants scheme was announced as a positive improvement for the tourist industry, but they reduced the amount of money that was going to be available. In the area of R&D, the 150 per cent tax concession was cut to 125 per cent, and something like $2 billion was cut out of R&D. Yet they said, `We will look after small business, because what we are saying is that small business is the engine room of Australia. But at the end of the day we are not going to provide you with the wherewithal to carry on and develop that engine that is going to drive the economy forward.' We then saw the government come forward and make its substantive attack on small business standards and we saw it looking at ways to try to improve them by bringing down the Prime Minister's own statement called More time for business, which was handed down on 24 March 1997.
It is illuminating to quote from that document. In the section on the economic importance of small business, the Prime Minister says:
Small business is the key to employment growth. In the decade to 1994-95—
and I ask my colleagues to reflect on who was in government in that decade—

the small business sector accounted for almost all of the one million net increase in jobs, increasing its work force by an estimated 1.1 million compared to 270,000 for large business and a decline in public sector employment of 150,000.
In other words, under the Labor government's stewardship, small business led the way in employment growth. We have seen nothing like that since this government came to power in this country.

What did the Prime Minister promise small business in this More time for business report? The small business innovation fund—after they cut $2 billion out of R&D—was cobbled together in the Prime Minister's office because there was nothing else he was going to agree to. When you read this response to Charlie Bell, all you see is a call for more inquiries and more committees to be established. They say, `We agree in principle with the recommendations but we are not going to do anything about it.'

No wonder it was considered to be a damp squib when somebody in the PM's office was putting it together and they suddenly said, `We need to have something that has a bit of shock value. What we will do is call something a small business innovation fund. We will throw $130 million at it. We will say that the industry has to match it, but don't tell anybody we cut $2 billion out of R&D and don't highlight the fact that it will only go to 100 firms in six categories and most of those in high-tech innovation—forget the rest—and this is going to solve the R&D problem in Australia.'

We then had a couple of other issues—capital gains tax, which we have agreed with, and the fringe benefits tax, which we have said was a small concession. It is terrific that small business people now need not pay fringe benefits tax when they get a taxi to work. That is the extent to which the Prime Minister thought the fringe benefits tax needed reform.

Then, of course there was the matter of the unfair dismissal laws. Out of the blue the Prime Minister suddenly said, `My unfair dismissal laws aren't any good anymore. My industrial relations laws that have been in place for five minutes are pretty ordinary and we are going to have to change them. We will change our own laws and exempt small business for 12 months under the unfair dismissal provisions.' In other words, they have removed protection from workers.

Because that went over like a lead balloon the Prime Minister decided to extend that to all small businesses and now potentially 1.3 million workers will not be covered by the industrial relations laws to protect them in their jobs. Yet this Prime Minister said, `We are going to protect jobs and we are going to create jobs through the small business sector.'
Then there was the 1997-98 budget. I know today we have had to remind the government that they brought a budget down two weeks ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was that?

—When was it? I cannot remember. It was two weeks today. Did it promise anything? Yes, it did. The core promise of John Howard, Prime Minister, doyen of small business, was that they would reduce compliance costs and red tape. What did the 1997-98 budget do? Small businesses have to offer each employee the choice of five superannuation funds. They have to give them some statement on each of those funds. Then they have to be a financial adviser to them and tell them which one to go into therefore opening up the potential for them to be sued as an employer if those investments go wrong. The paperwork burden has been increased because they have to collect potentially from each employee their contributions to five funds. I ask the Prime Minister: does that make a lot of sense in cutting red tape and compliance costs? I think it does not.

BREAK.PARA: Then there was the other rort about the withholding tax. That is going to give a benefit of $330 million to this government in its second year of operation. This was supposed to be a benefit. They said to small business, `Don't send in your withholding tax on a monthly basis. Do it every three months.' Small business is supposed to say, `That is a great idea. Why didn't I think of that?' Is it going to cost them anything? Yes, it will cost them time and effort because they will have to devote more time to filling in their forms every three months but the government—surprise, surprise!—gets a $330 million windfall in year two of this operation.

It is interesting to reflect on what some people—not I—have suggested about this government in its approach to small business. The superannuation spokesman from the Institute of Accountants, Robert Brown, said:
The decision to introduce a choice of five superannuation funds for employees would overwhelm small businesses with an implosion of paperwork.
He went on to say:
Combine this with the massive administration costs involved with the superannuation surcharge and you have almost an impossible situation.

A range of other comments were made by people in the industry itself about what this government has done for small business and how well it has gone. I thought probably the Chief Executive of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, Robert Bastian, got it right after the 1997‐98 budget. He said:
While this is a steady as she goes fiscally responsible budget, unfortunately in terms of employment the ship we are on is the Titanic .
He went on to say:

There continues to be no incentive for small business to employ. This is not a small business budget. It has been dramatically oversold and its few positives for small employers are far outweighed by an incredible sense of disappointment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—It was Rob Bastian, the spokesperson on small business, who is well quoted. Today saw the release of the Yellow Pages Small Business Index. As I reminded the Prime Minister in question time today, it found that small business confidence had reached its lowest level since August 1993. Eighty per cent of small business saw the economy as being in recession or at a standstill. It went on to say that only 22 per cent of people who were aware of the government's proposals to fix small business thought that it would improve their position and less than 10 per cent of all small businesses believed the initiatives would improve the situation.

BREAK.PARA: As I said in question time today, there is an answer for you people in government now. You are on the treasury benches and there is an answer. That answer is to adopt the recommendations of the fair trading inquiry report Finding a balance, unanimously supported by even people on your side of the parliament in respect of small business.

The recommendations contained in this report, whether they go to the issues of a uniform retail tenancy code, the misuse of market power on franchising or legislative protection against unfair conduct, are dealt with in the Beazley private member's bill, which lies on the table in this place, waiting to be brought on. This, Minister, is what small business wants. It wants codes underpinned by legislation. Your own backbenchers who conducted this inquiry said that that was what is required. Yet you said today in question time, `I'll get back to you in three months with a response as to what the government is going to do.' Minister, that is not good enough.

Last Tuesday night I was at a meeting in Melbourne. There were 1,000 angry retailers down there and their complaints all went to unconscionable conduct, to landlords having market power over them and to the fact that there was no franchising council in existence any longer. They pointed out in no uncertain terms to the Victorian small business minister that she needs to lift her game. Nationally, they pointed out that your government needs to lift its game as well. They overwhelmingly endorsed the fact that recommendations foreshadowed in the media and contained in this fair trading inquiry report need to be implemented.
Minister, you have the opportunity this afternoon, late in the day as it might be, not to look at that small business index and go back in history—because, mate, you're the government now—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member might address his remarks through the chair.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I say to the minister: they are the government and it is their responsibility to act—not go back in history and see where some of those tables might be, because I can throw up exactly the same sort of thing. In the 12 months since you have been in government, since you have been the minister, support for small business has gone through the floor. You have lost it, and you have lost them because you are not delivering.

BREAK.PARA: You stand up here, as does the Prime Minister, and spout nothing but rhetoric and say that you understand what small business needs. What small business needs is for this fair trading inquiry report to be adopted in full. It needs for the principles I enunciated recently on behalf of the opposition to be incorporated in that. It needs, as a first step, for the Kim Beazley private member's bill to be enacted as a matter of urgency. You don't even have to turn your brain to trying to think up a bill. It is there. It is the Beazley bill about unfair conduct and the minister should adopt it. He should immediately bring it into this place for consideration. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr PROSSER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to lay to rest the opposition's concerns in regard to small business. I particularly take this opportunity to outline to the people of Australia the achievements of this government in regard to small business.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition is trying to say that we have not been addressing the concerns of small business. That is quite contrary to, and a long way from, the truth. In fact, I will take a little time to outline the initiatives we have taken in regard to small business since coming to government. If you look at our policy focuses, particularly on coming to government and in the lead‐up to the election, you see that the important focus was a stable microeconomic climate for small business, industrial relations reform, changes to the tax system, a fair marketplace for small business and consumers, and the reduction of the compliance burden for small business.

In relation to a stable economic climate for small business, I remind the Labor opposition of what they did to small business. There is a legacy from the $10.3 billion budget deficit. This government has managed to turn a $10.3 billion budget deficit into a $1.6 billion budget surplus and will repay $5 billion worth of Commonwealth debt next year. That will be the first time in a decade the Commonwealth government has not borrowed.

What was the legacy of the previous government? Seventy billion dollars was borrowed, not for small business or ports or for any other infrastructure that would give our businesses the competitive edge but to try to fund the bottom line. It was wasted. It did not go to any initiatives. Small business paid a very high price in interest rates. As I said, this is the first time we have not borrowed. You clocked up $70 billion in just five years. We have turned a $10.3 billion budget deficit into a $1.6 billion budget surplus.
The reward for small business is the lowest interest rates in 25‐odd years. There have been three falls in interest rates during our term in government. They are now two per cent lower.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the economy is busted, that's why.

—I remind the member for Cunningham and businesspeople that in December 1989, during Labor's term in government, the prime interest rate was 20.5 per cent. Small businesses, with loading, were paying 24 and 25 per cent interest. No wonder they felt lost. They were neglected by you. You squeezed them. They went broke under you. You did not understand them. This government has provided a climate in which small business can expand, grow and have more certainty. This government understands small business. I acknowledge that things have been very difficult for them. The economy has been patchy in parts for them. We are out there listening to their concerns, to ensure that we turn that around.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at our policy initiatives set out during the election campaign in the document `A new deal for small business'. That policy spoke of achieving, within 100 days of our coming to office: the setting up of the deregulation task force, mentioned just a moment ago; a small business summit, which we have had; and the setting up of the microbusiness consultative group. We said we would do it, and we delivered. We also said that we would set up the regulatory efficiency area, particularly in microbusiness. A report was handed to the Prime Minister on 1 November. The government responded on 24 March. We went a long way further than that report recommended, particularly in the areas of red tape and compliance.

Mr Deputy Speaker, let us look for a moment at what the previous government did. They had a report. Do you remember it? The Beddall report. I have mentioned already in the House how I got my copy of it out and dusted it off. That is all that happened to everyone's copy of that report—all it did was collect one heck of a lot of dust because those opposite dropped it real quick. But let us look at it. It is their response to red tape and compliance.
Mr Fitzgibbon interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Hunter!
—`Paperwork reduction plan', they called it. Let us look at their great innovation.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Fitzgibbon interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is three.

—What will they do to reduce red tape and compliance? This is what they will do. `After the implementation of the changes concerned, we're going to put time boxes on all the forms. We're going to do nothing except put time boxes on so that you can fill out more forms and more time boxes.' They were not cutting it by 50 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: What did we propose to do? In our More time for business we proposed, and are sticking to, a 50 per cent cut in red tape. As a former business person myself, I know the frustration of red tape and filling out compliance forms. Looking back over the course of just the last 12 years, what did I as a businessman have to comply with? Capital gains tax: they brought it in; fringe benefits tax: they brought it in; unfair dismissal laws: they brought them in; the super guarantee: they brought it in.

BREAK.PARA: They are the sorts of things that small business now has to comply with that it did not have to comply with. They are the sorts of things we are trying to make simpler for them. We are trying to remove the burden of that sort of thing from small business.

I have mentioned capital gains tax. In our policy document there was reference to capital gains tax. In fact, we offered a capital gains tax rollover provision. What of the Beddall report? They brought it in on 19 September 1985. They said, `Oh, we might do something about this.' One million bucks is what they said. Did they ever do anything about it? No, they did nothing. We come in: $5 million every five years; remove the `like kind' business test, making it for all business, whatever you want to do; and, of course, our retirement package.

Small businesses build up their businesses as a retirement nest egg—and that is something the Labor opposition have never understood. Under our proposal: build up your business and retire at age 55 and above; each partner can take $500,000 capital gains tax free—$1 million capital gains tax free.

It is no wonder that the industry organisations describe our package in such glowing terms. In particular, Robert Gottliebsen in the BRW said, `The small business capital gains tax rollover is the most significant change ever made to taxation in Australia for decades'—and quite right he was. So capital gains tax is another major factor.

Provisional tax uplift factor from eight per cent down to six per cent—they did not do it; we did it. Fringe benefits tax and more time for business arrangements—we simplified and removed FBT for small business on car parking; record keeping was simplified, including the removal of record keeping in connection with taxi travel. With industrial relations, our Workplace Relations Act sweeps away Labor's unfair dismissal laws.

TALK.START.PARA: —And now you want to amend it.
—Order! The member for Cunningham was heard in silence.

—They do not really want me to talk about unfair dismissal laws. That is probably why the interjections came at that point. They, in fact, do not want to talk about unfair dismissal laws. We offered—in fact, we wanted—to remove the compliance of unfair dismissal for small businesses of 15 employees and below—and who announced that they would oppose it? These guys. They do not understand small business. They do not understand that the greatest concern to small business was, of course, the unworkable unfair dismissal laws.

BREAK.PARA: Look at the other initiatives: the retirement savings, the micro-business consultative group that we have set up, access to capital. The member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) briefly mentioned in a derogatory manner the small business innovation fund. That is something that has been missing in the Australian small business sector for all too long. They have not understood that, for most small business, you can only grow effectively with debt financing. Your ability to grow gets to the point of servicing your debt, plus retained earnings. You have not had the vehicle through an equity market. What we have done with the small business innovation fund, in particular, is put that in place.

I am particularly disappointed that the opposition has not recognised the things that are important to small business. But as they now after 13 years have discovered small business, let us look at what they are proposing. I noted with interest in the 24 February report in the Melbourne Age headed `Labor reviews party platform' that they had 15 points—15 important platforms. I thought, `This is interesting; small business is bound to be at the top of the list.' Was small business at the top of the list? Was small business even on their list? Small business was not even on the list.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's there now.

—It is there now. The shadow minister says, `It's there now.' He has come up now with seven points: small business policy principles—they are so wishy-washy. They are talking about growth in the economy. Wow, what they did to small business and growth in the economy! I have to tell the shadow spokesperson that he has a long way to go if he thinks that those sorts of things are what small businesses want.

BREAK.PARA: Small businesses want government off their back. The interesting thing is that a moment ago the former minister was in here, and he reported that what small businesses want is government off their back. We are delivering that, particularly with regard to red tape and compliance reforms. What he does not realise is that small businesses do not want the uncertainty of massive swings in interest rates that were the ploy particularly of their policies. What small businesses want is some certainty with regard to their business decisions.

I mentioned briefly the Beddall report. Quite frankly, why it gathered dust was because they did not deliver. They did not deliver on capital gains tax. All they could come up with in the red tape and compliance area was to have extra forms in boxes, thinking that would solve the problem.

I think, more importantly, we should go to what the industry sector is saying. My colleague did say, `This is what the industry organisations are saying.' I have mentioned the BRW. Of course, in describing our capital gains tax rollover provision, the BRW said, `Tax breaks give small business room to move.' And, `Fruit is on the tree, take the advantage; make decisions in regard to business planning now.' In relation to growth and conditions, VECCI says, `Long awaited responses to deregulation report is worth the wait.' Its following media release says, `Government response delivers for small business.'

The Australian Business Chamber says, `The small business report is a significant booster.' The real estate sector says, `Government response shows strong sensitivity to the pressures facing small business.' The opposition does not like hearing this at all. The Institute of Chartered Accountants said—and, from memory, my colleague mentioned something about this area—`For the first time in many years the small business community has a government that has shown it is prepared to listen and make changes.'

It is no wonder that they say that. After 13 years of being ignored, they now have a government that is prepared to listen and make changes. The institute went on to say, `In its first term of office, the government has demonstrated a commitment to encouraging and assisting small and medium sized enterprises rarely witnessed in modern times.' The opposition does not like that because we recognise the importance of small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was that?

—In March of this year. We recognise and the Prime Minister recognises the importance of small business. We are doing what we can in a very positive way to assist them. Let me turn to the newspaper headlines. `Relief at last for small business.' The headlines tell it all. `Taxation relief for small business'. `Funds for small firms on the way'. The opposition does not like those sorts of initiatives.

BREAK.PARA: My colleague opposite made some passing reference to franchising. I can advise the House that, in the last year of the previous government, its funding to the Franchising Code Council was some $375,000. In the first year of our government, our funding was $648,000. Those opposite call that a cut. We indicated another $152,000 next year—

TALK.START.PARA: —You abolished it.
—We did not.
