SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —After that complacent and self-satisfied performance from the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser), I feel compelled to relay to the House that, according to the Daily Telegraph on 2 May, the minister for small business, when attempting to sell his government's small business message, conceived a series of pep talks and breakfasts in capital cities. He dispatched no fewer than 3,000 invitations. By late 1 May—the day before—the Sydney breakfast had attracted a total of 30 RSVPs.

SPEECH.PARA: Stung by the poor response, Minister Prosser ordered the Sydney branch of his department—all 15 of them—to attend the function to help boost the numbers. The Daily Telegraph referred to him as the minister for small turnouts. I have to admit that the minister's performance made me feel a whole lot better, because some of my fundraising efforts have been less than stunning successes—but just 30, oh dear!

Small businesses are very busy, as we all know, particularly in these days of deregulated shop trading hours and increased competition for the retail dollar from the casino, poker machines and the like. But they will turn up if an issue really affects them. The minister's minuscule audience simply reflects the fact that there is nothing that his government is saying which is relevant to the concerns of small business. They will turn up if the issue is important.

Last Tuesday—a week ago—not 30 people but more than 1,000 small business people, retail tenants and franchisees turned up to a public meeting in Melbourne organised by Lisa Michael of the United Retailers Association and chaired by Steve Price of 3AW. That was a terrific meeting, but it was also an angry meeting, because many of the people there have seen their livelihoods ruined as a result of the way they have been treated by shopping centre managements.

There was a woman from Box Hill shopping centre who, with her husband, has lost her home. They are now living in a caravan park. There was a man from Northlands shopping centre who cannot pay the rent because the eastern end of the centre is being renovated and his customers—rather than walk through a construction site—are going elsewhere. When he asked for a rent reduction while the works were going on, the shopping centre management told him that he ought to declare himself bankrupt. There are many more outrageous cases, with people aged 50 and over losing the assets that they have worked for all their lives and staring down the financial barrel.

At last Tuesday's meeting, I moved two motions that were carried unanimously. The first dealt with the Victorian situation. It urged the Victorian government to establish a retail tenancies tribunal with wide ranging powers to arbitrate disputes between landlords and retail tenants.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't hold your breath.

—Indeed. The second urged the federal government to support amendments to the Trade Practices Act which would prevent harsh or oppressive conduct by retail landlords and franchisors, and would give the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission greater powers to stamp out such conduct. That unanimous resolution, as I pointed out to the meeting and as members of this House would recognise, picks up Kim Beazley's private member's bill on better business conduct—a bill which Labor tried to enact in government and has since pursued in opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, the minister for small business and the Liberal government have refused to support or pass this bill. They talk the talk of small business. They tell small business, `We're on your side,' but when it comes down to the crunch they support big business. Retail tenants and franchisees are being exploited just as coalminers and shearers were in the previous century. They need more than words from the Liberal Party.

The bad news for those opposite is that the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin), state opposition leader John Brumby and I told those retail tenants that last Tuesday night, and they understood it from their own bitter experience.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a team.

—Indeed. If last week's meeting was exciting, yesterday's fair trading report was even more so. Having appeared before the inquiry, I was impressed with the grasp that those committee members had of the issues involved and their apparent sincerity and determination to do something about it.

SPEECH.PARA: That report is a gem. It has certainly exceeded my expectations. The committee members who prepared it, both Labor and Liberal, should take a bow. It is really something for them to tell the kids and the grandkids about once their parliamentary days are over—about a blow that they have struck for justice and fairness in retailing in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —It talked to small businesses.

—This is a report which comes from a committee which, as my colleague the member for Rankin said, did not just talk about small business but talked to small business. And don't the recommendations show it? It talks about a retail tenancy code which would establish specialist retail lease tribunals for quick and inexpensive dispute resolution. It talks about security of tenure for retail tenants, including rights to renewal of leases. It talks about market rent reviews only to be permitted on the renewal of a lease, and disclosure statements to outline provisions for rent reduction in the event of changes in the tenancy of a shopping centre. It talks about disclosure statements specifying how compensation will be awarded for disturbance to trading caused by the redevelopment of shopping centres and relocation of tenants. So no more of this `Heads we win, tails you lose' attitude from shopping centre owners.

SPEECH.PARA: We need change. Look at some of the bankruptcy figures for recent months. In the quarter from January to March this year, parts 4 and 11 bankruptcies were 5,351 in 1997 compared with 4,413 in 1996—a rise in excess of 20 per cent. This is a government that says it is delivering for small business, and you have got bankruptcies up in excess of 20 per cent. There is a similar situation in the year to date: in 1996‐97 bankruptcies were 15,910, 27 per cent up on the figure for 1995-96. That is the way they are delivering for small business.

That we also need change is apparent when we look at the recommendations and some of the evidence that is put forward in the fair trading inquiry report. For example, Mary Caruana, who had a restaurant in the Box Hill Central Shopping Centre, told the committee that on one occasion when the tenants wanted to have a meeting centre management reacted by ordering the security guards to lock the doors and turn off the lights at closing time, notwithstanding there were still customers in the centre who had to leave by a trade entrance. That is the attitude they take towards tenants even daring to have a meeting.

Later on in the report there is a case study of a relocation where the proprietor of a toy shop in Campbelltown in New South Wales was told that they should relocate their operation and that no other toy stores would be allowed in there. It may be convenient, but there is no need to buy a pound of spuds or a new hat at 2 o'clock in the morning; it is a nonsense. There is no doubt that 24‐hour trading will see the demise of small business in the retail sector. We have seen large shopping centres consistently give the big client a rent based on a percentage of turnover, but they charge the small businesses per square foot with inflation clauses. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fahey, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

The amendments to the AIDC Sale Bill 1997 made by the Senate formalise the position which the government had already stated: that it would quarantine the Australian Submarine Corporation shareholding from the sale of AIDC Ltd. These amendments place a statutory obligation on the Minister for Finance to transfer the shares in the Submarine Corporation to the Australian Industry Development Corporation, the parent statutory authority which is not proposed for sale.

The amendments make use of the existing ministerial powers of transfer in the AIDC Sale Bill and so ensure that the other provisions in the bill retain the appropriate cross‐referencing. The amendments then place a restriction on the corporation to prevent it from selling the shareholding in the ASC to a foreign person. This is defined using the meaning provided by the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act.

Amendment (1) makes some technical changes to section 33K to require the registration of the shareholdings. Amendment (2) is a substantive amendment which inserts a new section 33KA after section 33K to make specific provision for the shares in the ASC.

Subsection (1) of that proposed new section provides that, if an AIDC body holds the legal or beneficial interest in ASC shares, then the Minister for Finance must use the powers already in the bill to make a declaration to vest those shares in the Australian Industry Development Corporation. That power must be exercised before 1 September 1997. Provision is made for the move of the shares to the corporation to be made directly or through a series of steps. This flexibility recognises that the shares in ASC are held by a succession of wholly owned subsidiaries of AIDC Ltd. There may be a practical or legal reason for moving the shares through the subsidiaries rather than directly. The drafting provides the flexibility necessary, recognising the commercial nature of the arrangement.

Subsection (2) of the proposed new section provides that the Australian Industry Development Corporation may subsequently sell or transfer the ASC shares. However, under subsection (3), the corporation must not sell or transfer the shares to a foreign person within the meaning of the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act, except where there are pre‐emptive rights.

The Australian Submarine Corporation Pty Ltd is a private company in which the shareholders can be under obligations to other shareholders in the event of sale or transfer of the shares. As the ASC is a private company, there may be in existence pre‐emptive rights of acquisition of other parties' shares. These rights could be held by each of the shareholders.

By placing the statutory restriction on the exercising of those rights by one of the shareholders, it could be argued that the Commonwealth was appropriating the economic interests of that party, giving rise to a claim for compensation or possibly undermining the validity of that provision. The amendment is drafted and protects those rights but, in exercising those rights, the foreign party would have to demonstrate that they existed and that they were not inconsistent with other statutory restrictions that may have applied at the time of conferring those rights. Subsections (3) and (4) are for clarification and definition purposes.

In effect, the amendments give affect to the government's general approach to the ASC's shareholding. Although the same result could have effectively been achieved without them, they are supported by the government as clarifying the position with respect to this important strategic asset.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the requested amendments be made.

The Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill 1996 establishes the largest commitment to environmental management in Australia's history. The Australian community has long demanded a serious and committed approach by government towards the restoration and maintenance of the environment and towards ensuring that agricultural production is undertaken truly sustainably. The coalition is now delivering this.

Over the next five years $1.25 billion will be invested through the Natural Heritage Trust. The Natural Heritage Trust will introduce a coordinated and integrated policy approach, which has been sadly lacking in the past; it will provide an enormous increase in the level of funding for landcare and many other initiatives; it will provide funding certainty for future years; and it will provide a far greater proportion of spending on the ground and in the water where it matters. This is what the Australian community has de manded of government for so long—and the coalition has delivered just what is needed.

Some minor amendments have been made to the bill in the Senate, and today we have an opportunity to formally consider them. The amendments listed as schedule A amendments are those sought by the government and will, firstly, allow an increase in the trust capital of $100 million; secondly, fix the trust's minimum balance at $300 million; and, thirdly, establish arrangements for interest earned by the trust.

The schedule B amendments also derive from the Senate and, whilst not originating with the government, are acceptable to the government. They include, firstly, that there should be clarification that agreements for reserve funding can be entered jointly as well as separately by both the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for the Environment; secondly, establishing the Natural Heritage Trust Advisory Committee; thirdly, changing the name of the board to the Natural Heritage Ministerial Board; and, fourthly, making revisions to the preamble.

The Natural Heritage Trust will bring considerable benefit to current and future generations of Australians. It will provide an integrated and coordinated approach towards land, water, vegetation and biodiversity management. It will provide $1.25 billion over five years, which is a huge increase on any government commitment of the past. The Natural Heritage Trust will provide much needed funding for community groups to undertake work on the full range of environmental challenges we face—whether it be the enhancement of our land and water resources, the protection of our native animal and plant species, the improvement of our rivers, estuaries and wetlands, the widespread planting of trees, the control of feral animals and weeds or the cleaning up of our beaches and coastal regions.

This is a very exciting program, which will bring about significant environmental improvements for this and future generations. It is important for rural and regional Australia, as it will provide assistance to community groups to undertake much needed on‐ground works. This, in turn, will create a sustainable resource base for primary industries for the future so they can continue to prosper and bring continued benefits to rural and urban communities.

The coalition is serious about both the environment and sustainable agricultural production. This is a very important moment for this House and for this nation. I call on all members of the House to support this historic bill, which will deliver considerable long-term benefits to the nation and its people.

(3) continues the assault on families, the elderly and the needy;
(4) contains many mindless and counter‐productive cuts affecting the quality and decency of life in Australia, and harming our international reputation;

(5) for all its cuts and destructive impact, did not meet the exaggerated expectations the Government had created as to the size of its deficit reduction achievements and projected future surpluses; and
(6) has been characterised by even the Government's best friends as lacking in shape, direction and vision".

Let me begin in talking about this budget with its contribution to savings which the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has said on multiple occasions over the last two weeks is the central theme and the central achievement of this budget. He cannot be very thrilled with the reception that it has been given on this front—many commentators making clear their concern. Ross Gittins, in the Sydney Morning Herald on 14 May, belled the cat most succinctly when he said:
This budget is a confidence track. It purports to be all about increasing national savings, but in fact it will reduce them.

Those criticisms have been very well founded. Let us look at the arithmetic for a start. The Treasurer's headline surplus has been achieved essentially by windfall gains through selling off more than $10 billion worth of public assets, reducing public debt, yes, and public debt interest obligations, yes, but making, as economists would recognise, a zero contribution to national savings.

His underlying surplus of $1.6 billion, to be achieved by 1998-99, is to be realised as follows. There is $330 million from a one-off windfall gain from a timing change to withholding tax payment arrangements, dressed up as a major benefit to small business but in fact only benefiting the very smallest businesses; most of those with more than four employees are in fact being left out in the cold. Three hundred and ten million dollars of it is a public debt interest saving, the largest part of which comes from the government's last minute decision to force Telstra to take on another $3 billion in debt, putting pressure on future telephone charges—as we are seeing already with indications of new 013 charges—and not improving national saving one iota. The sum of $267 million is from additional property sales in 1998-99, allowed to be counted by a technical loophole in the definition of `net advances'. So much for Mr Costello's claim in January that he had ended `forever the last minute asset sales to mask the true state of the accounts'. Of course, the final $729 million is achieved by the government breaking its superannuation co‐contribution promise in a way which will diminish— as I will explain in a moment—rather than massively enhance the national savings pool.

To the extent that the overall deficit reduction and surplus creating outcomes have been achieved by straight‐out outlays reductions, as distinct from these other various windfalls I have just described, that was far more the achievement of the decisions made in last year's budget than those made in this one. That is another reason that the budget received such a lacklustre reception, to put it politely, from the financial markets.

I hasten to add that, from the opposition perspective, this is not one of the criticisms that we make of this budget. We thought last year's slashing was far too draconian, both in its specific impacts on jobs, on support for families and on good public policy generally and in its overall contractionary impact on the economy, taking half a per cent at least off the growth that was otherwise achievable last year and next. Again, although the cuts and the slashes in this year's budget were certainly bad enough, we think that the government's continued obsession with budget deficit reduction and its obsession with improving national saving through reducing public dissaving in this way represents simply misguided priorities.

International comparisons I think continue to be instructive in this respect. At least the government has been shamed into putting some of them back into the budget papers after omitting them last year. I am talking in particular about comparative public debt and government deficit statistics, because this indicates perhaps better than anything else the misguided nature of the government's slashing and burning enterprise.

In Europe, honourable members will be aware, the Maastricht convergence criteria for good economic housekeeping for economic monetary union in Europe do set some maximum limits as to what is permissible, with 60 per cent of GDP being the maximum permissible public debt and three per cent being the maximum permissible government deficit across the country. Of course, efforts to meet those criteria for monetary union have been causing massive political and social unrest in a number of European countries at the moment, most obviously last weekend with the first round French assembly elections producing for many people the unexpected result of a massive protest vote against the government.

There is only one European country—Luxembourg—which meets those criteria at the moment in full. But Australia easily meets them. Australia bolts it in. We have at the moment around 40 per cent gross public debt, compared with the European average of 78 per cent. We have less than one per cent of GDP in budget deficits, with that figure likely to come down further in the years ahead. The message from the opposition about all this has been exactly the same every time we have said it since the election. Yes, the budget balances are, over the course of the economic cycle, a worthy objective, other things being equal. But it is not an objective that should be manically pursued if larger problems are going unredressed, or if to pursue manic budget deficit reduction objectives is in manifest conflict with other more sensible economic priorities and, in particular in our situation at the moment, with reducing the utterly unacceptable and tragic close to nine per cent unemployment rate which continues to apply.

The Labor government's performance in deficit reduction was much more successful than the coalition's if you look at it in straight‐out dollar terms. We took $6.8 billion off the deficit in our last two years in office. The coalition has managed to take off only $6.4 billion in its first two budgets. We did make a big fiscal consolidation effort, but the main reason we got there and the main reason we achieved those outcomes was our much greater concentration and focus on growing the economy. The priority that is sensibly given to growth in this situation is something I will come back to in a moment.

The centrepiece of the government's budget is the so-called savings rebate. It is worth while spelling out in just a little bit of detail what an ill thought out, valueless, half‐baked exercise it was to replace the co‐ contribution scheme with the so-called savings rebate. In the first place, its impact on total national saving is bound to end up negative. That is because the rebate rewards those with existing savings—even if they run down during the course of the year—rather than those making new ones, and the government rebate itself is far more likely to be spent than saved.

That contrasts with the Labor Party's co‐contribution scheme, which the coalition itself previously embraced, whereby the $4.5 billion that we were going to spend on government superannuation contributions, matched as it had to be by the three per cent wage earners contribution, would have provided a net gain to national savings of close to that full amount. That would have translated over the period to 2020 into a $400 billion addition to the national savings pool. Under this government's savings rebate scheme, that amount simply disappears. So much for reducing our foreign debt, so much for reducing our dependence on foreign investment, so much for being better able to buy back the farm.

In the second place, the new savings rebate is not going to make any effective contribution to people's long-term retirement income packages. Under the co-contribution scheme someone now on average weekly earnings aged 35 would be collecting an additional retirement benefit of $110,000. That disappears under the government's savings rebate scheme.

In the third place, the savings rebate scheme is full of anomalies and inequities. How can it contribute to the development of a savings `culture' in this country when you can get it by not adding to your saving? Why was the system designed so that not one of the 1.3 million full rate aged and service pensioners can get the rebate, even if they have income on their savings of up to $2,500, while any taxpayer earning that amount on his or her savings would get a rebate of $375?

Why was it designed to enable business income earned as a sole trader or through a partnership or trust to count for the rebate provided only it is not described as wages or salary? Why should it be possible for a wealthy family to distribute its saving income through a family trust structure to, say, five tax paying members of the family, each of them getting the maximum $450 rebate? What is the comparative merit of a scheme which means that an ordinary worker paying $1,000 in personal superannuation contributions will get $150 from the rebate whereas under the co-contribution scheme there would have been a matching contribution of fully $1,000?

How many low to middle income earners can afford to pay personal superannuation contributions of $3,000 a year, or $58 a week, to get the full benefit of the rebate? How many of them have the $60,000 in savings in the bank or elsewhere that would be the other way of getting the full $450?

How can it be just for high income earners—the great majority of whom are paying more than $3,000 into superannuation already or who already have more than $60,000 in other savings—to be getting the rebate? Why on earth did John Howard, the Prime Minister, say that it would be `stupid' and `crazy' for there to be a means test on the rebate when his own pre-election savings document promised a means test on any savings incentive that the coalition introduced?

It is no exaggeration to say that the coalition savings rebate—which can, at the end of the day, be characterised as nothing more than a windfall tax cut for those who do not need it—is one of the worst designed, most indefensible and cynical pieces of public policy making in the financial history of this country. It is lousy economics, lousy social policy and lousy morality. The government will properly stand condemned for it.

The other thing I want to say about the savings rebate is to contest the proposition that somehow a unique initiative is being introduced by this government, that there has not previously been anything which operates as an incentive for saving. That is palpable nonsense and let me tell you why. There has been a whole series of savings tax incentives introduced by Labor over the years.

Let me make a list of the major ones. For a start, every reduction in marginal tax rates reduces the tax rates on savings. Labor massively reduced the rates of income tax applying at all income levels with the largest proportion of cuts being the basic rate of tax reduced from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. Again, the value of the assistance to saving via superannuation increased dramatically under Labor from around $2.37 billion in 1983‐84 to $6.3 billion in 1995-96. We not only massively increased the amount of assistance to this form of savings but significantly increased the availability of superannuation to the general public, thus making the tax expenditure here a lot fairer.

A system of full dividend imputation introduced by Labor is delivering around $3 billion worth of tax reductions to savings through shares. That is not providing some kind of rort, but it is ending the previous system of double taxation of company income which previously applied. Full tax is paid on company income, but double tax is eliminated.

Division 7 tax was abolished in 1986, delivering hundreds of millions of dollars in savings per year to those small businesses who were allowed to save and reinvest their earnings instead of having to distribute them and hence pay personal tax to top up the company tax already paid. Again, the management and investment companies scheme provided a tax deduction for savings in venture capital companies. Even though that scheme was ultimately terminated, that provided the catalyst for the current venture or development capital industry that is now starting to flourish in Australia. So let us hear no more of that nonsense.

I focused on the savings question because the Treasurer has made so much of it. The other very big point to make about this budget is the utter inability of this budget to deal with the question of jobs—job creation, job security. Let me say very briefly, because I have said all this before in the MPI debate in this place the day after the budget, that if we are going to create the jobs necessary to significantly and quickly reduce unemployment to less tragic levels in this country there has to be at least five major strategies adopted. Not one of those strategies is given appropriate support in this budget.

The first thing you have to do, which this budget did not, is grow internal demand by growing the economy as a whole at a faster rate. Unless you do get it coming in at over four per cent, that simply will not create the preconditions that everybody now agrees are necessary for significant unemployment reduction. Instead, you have another contractionary budget, another series of expenditure cuts, which actually reduces jobs rather than creates them.

About the only contribution to growth overall that the budget made was to shame the Reserve Bank into making a compensatory further reduction in interest rates last week. This was not a matter, as the Prime Minister keeps saying, of the budget being so great as to make the interest rate cut possible. Rather, it is because the budget was so bad that interest rate cut was desperately necessary.

The second thing any job creating strategy has to do is link Australia into external demand through properly supported and properly funded trade and external affairs policy. You do not do that by cutting departmental and Austrade resources. You do not do it by removing the funding and killing the National Trade and Investment Outlook Conference, which this budget has done.

The third thing, and a very big thing, the budget should have done for jobs but did not was to provide major support to translate generalised demand into specific business and job opportunities through carefully crafted industry policy and regional development policy. There is no such thing as industry policy under this government. It has now been abandoned. There is no such thing as regional policy. The budget systematically continues the task begun last year of hacking away at those crucial props.

The fourth thing the budget has to do for jobs each year but did not do on this occasion when it was so desperately necessary is to reverse the damage that has been done to education, to training, to job readiness programs. Labour market programs have been cut to pieces. It is just desperately damaging to have further cuts on top of that to vocational education, to abolish the Commonwealth industry places scheme, to generally display a total lack of interest that this budget does in getting these things right.

BREAK.PARA: The next and last thing the budget needs to do in this situation is provide more resources for the creation of a publicly funded pool of essentially transitional community service jobs to try to absorb, at least for the time it takes other strategies to effectively bite, some of that large group of people whose skills are going to be in less demand and who need that kind of support. Killing LEAP, offering a few hundred places by way of compensation in the Green Corps and offering 10,000 opportunities to work for the dole is no substitute for providing meaningful and rewarding work, the training that goes with it and some sense of security.

The basic difference between the government and the opposition on all of this is that we have a different idea of the bottom line. It is not just the accountant's bottom line; it is the human bottom line. There has to be something about the view from Kirribilli and the view from Toorak and Malvern that simply stops the Prime Minister and the Treasurer from seeing that human bottom line. Above all, they seem to have failed utterly to understand how serious is the human plight of those 800,000 Australians who want to work but who presently cannot and who have been utterly demoralised over the last year to see their chances of work getting no better but in fact getting worse. If the government does not want to accept the responsibilities of leadership, it ought to step aside for a party that demonstrably can and will. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zammit, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened very attentively to what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Gareth Evans) had to say. According to him, everything in the budget is wrong—the direction is wrong, the vision is wrong. Here we saw a former senior minister of the former government with not a single hint of contriteness in his address. We were left with a huge foreign debt and a $10.3 billion budget deficit. On top of that, the credit rating of Australia was downgraded not just once but twice in the final six years of the former Labor government.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now about nine months since the new Howard-Fischer government brought down the first coalition government budget in 13 years, generally seen as a tough but fair budget. The plan of action was then detailed to redress the years of Hawke-Keating Labor government budgets that pursued a policy of deficit and debt, a policy that saw little inclination to take tough decisions in the long-term interests of our nation and a policy that resulted in Australia's overseas debt blowing out to unheard of proportions.

That policy also resulted in a Commonwealth general net debt in excess of $93 billion, a budget deficit of more than $10 billion and Australia having to suffer the ignominy and shame, for the first time in our nation's history, of being downgraded by the world's major credit rating agencies from our AAA credit rating not just once but twice in the last six years of that government. Deficit and debt are the hallmarks of the legacy of Labor.

It is interesting to note that in its last five years the former Labor government ran up $70 billion in deficits, averaging $17 billion a year. Treasurer Costello has turned a $10.3 billion deficit around to a surplus in 1998-99 of $1.6 billion. The Treasurer has set the scene in this plan for a steady, decades‐long growth—no more of the boom and bust of Labor with the recession we `had to have'.

This budget provides the framework for steady growth, low inflation, low interest rates, Commonwealth outlays at pre-Whitlam levels and a budget in surplus, with a growing economy at 3¾ per cent and perhaps even higher. Just as importantly, this will obviate the need to borrow this year or next year on the long road to repaying our debt. In other words, we are at last beginning to pay our way through a reduction in spending instead of a lifting of revenue.

Not only will the Commonwealth not be borrowing, but in fact the process of repaying our debt has begun—a debt left to us through the former Labor administration's mismanagement of the Australian economy. The repay ment of the debt will be at the impressive rate of $5 billion in the coming financial year, with a further $5 billion the following year.

Also, for the first time in more than a decade the Commonwealth is going to tax savings less, and the tax system is going to be biased in favour of savings. National savings have fallen steadily for the past 13 or so years. As a result, investments which create jobs and improve the socioeconomic standards of our society have exponentially dried up. The cornerstone of the Howard-Costello financial strategy is the increasing of national savings through an increase of public savings. It remains an undeniable fact that, even though we form part of the global economy—in particular I refer to the capital markets—those nations whose people save money have higher levels of business investment than nations whose people do not. Domestic savings that are clearly identifiable are exactly what Australia needs to advance economic growth and reverse unemployment trends.

If there is a highlight to the budget, a point of emphasis, then it must be in reference to savings. In the recession, the one we `had to have', the rate of national savings as a percentage of GDP was at a very low 16 per cent. That has steadily improved since the Howard government came to power on 2 March 1996 to about 18 per cent currently. However, even that improvement leaves us well short of the 25 per cent of GDP experienced in the 1950s and 1960s, which is the level we have to aim for.

The savings rebate contained in the budget goes some of the way to redressing the injustice felt especially by self-funded retirees. The bulk of self-funded retirees are people who have sacrificed all their lives to not become a burden on governments when they retire. Many, if not most, retire on fixed incomes and have to rely on their investment and/or superannuation just to survive.

There will be a rebate on interest on bank account savings, superannuation contributions, share dividends, and also on rents from properties. That rebate will be at the rate of 15 per cent on savings worth up to $450 a year on taxable income from savings of up to a maximum of $3,000. These measures will be brought in over two stages, with a 7½ per cent redebate from 1 July 1998 and the full rebate from 1 July 1999. The major incentive to savings in this budget is the fact that the government is strenuously setting about the task of repairing years of mismanagement by returning the underlying budget balance to a sufficient surplus to meet the accruing costs of government initiatives.

Unemployment, which is forecast to go down to about eight per cent, continues to be Australia's major economic and social problem. However, that level, if attained—and I am confident that it will be—will be the lowest level for the past eight years. The Howard coalition government in the past year has created 130,000 new jobs, and the forecast in this year's budget is for 200,000 additional jobs. The coalition government's plan of action with a budget surplus in 1998-99, the underlying inflation rate at only two per cent—one of the lowest in the world—and interest rates at their lowest for more than a quarter of a century puts the Howard government well on target for a reduction of unemployment to under eight per cent by the middle of next year.

The other good news I want to refer to is the Commonwealth general government net debt which is set to fall from over 19 per cent of GDP in 1995‐96 to under 10.5 per cent in the years 2000-2001—a huge turnaround, almost halving our public debt levels as a percentage of our GDP that has restricted our economic growth prospects. That, if it were left unaddressed, would have resulted in many future generations of Australians having to shoulder the debt.

I turn now to the issue of the family and what is being done to assist them primarily through the $1 billion family tax initiative, which is beginning to provide substantial assistance for low and middle income families. Additionally, on 1 July this year, the $450 rebate on the cost of private health insurance will come into effect. The new initiatives announced in this budget by the Treasurer will further assist families in need, especially some of the most disadvantaged—and I refer specifically to those who look after elderly relatives and/or children with disabilities.

The domiciliary nursing care benefit will be aligned from 1 July 1998 with the child disability allowance to assist carers who provide home based care as against nursing home care, with an extra $16.60 per fortnight. Also effective from 1 July 1998, those caring for children under the age of 16 with severe disabilities will become eligible for carer payment. This means that a full-time carer will be eligible to receive up to $347.80 per fortnight. Further, additional funding of $54 million spread over four years will be provided under the Commonwealth-state disability agreement for additional support for accommodation for people with severe disabilities.

I want to turn now specifically to two coalition plans, which are visionary: the first, through the Natural Heritage Trust, has the potential to largely repair the destruction successive generations have inflicted on our environment; and the second, through the Federation Fund, looks to the future for the celebration of our centenary of federation. The Natural Heritage Trust is provided with $1¼ billion to fund the largest ever rescue operation, with the greatest possible urgency, for our greatest national inheritance—and that is the environment—to save our rivers, vegetation and land. The Federation Fund will consist of $1 billion to fund projects of special national importance in commemoration of the forthcoming centenary celebrations of our federation, which occurred on 1 January 1901.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pork‐barrelling.

—I cannot let that interjection from the honourable member for Watson go unanswered. He called it pork‐barrelling. Repairing the environment that successive generations have not taken responsibility for, and providing a Federation Fund—something that we should all be very proud of—he refers to as pork‐barrelling; all the jobs that will be provided to help young Australians especially, he calls pork‐barrelling. I believe that comment will come back to haunt the honourable member for Watson.

BREAK.PARA: These projects will be especially selected to create jobs in the construction phase, and will also be chosen to honour our achievements as a nation since federation. I am particularly glad to see that one of the projects will include a National Museum of Australia. I would hope to see a significant portion of that museum dedicated to the collation of the history and other related memorabilia surrounding migration to Australia, which I think is much needed before all this memorabilia and these parts of Australia's history are perhaps lost forever.

As I move around the electorate, I am heartened by ordinary average Australians who say to me that they are aware that in just two budgets we cannot—and neither are we expected to—repair 13 years of boom and bust cycles and the deficit and debt mind‐set of the former Labor government. They also tell me that they want a plan of action for a better and fairer Australia.

I pay tribute tonight to the Treasurer for providing in this budget the plan of action for his and the Prime Minister's perceptive view of the aspirations of our fellow Australians, with an emphasis on small business, families, reduction of debt, budget outcomes and jobs, jobs, jobs. I can think of no better note to finish on in expressing my strong support for the appropriation bill 1997-98.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second coalition government budget was part of a specific plan for a better Australia—a plan to keep inflation and interest rates low, a plan to cut debt, a plan to help families, a plan to assist small business and a plan to deliver jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: In March 1996 the coalition inherited Labor's legacy: $10,000 million of deficit. We also inherited Labor's legacy of $70,000 million of public debt. The good news in this year's budget is that, by 1998-99, the $10.3 billion deficit will turn into a $1.6 billion surplus. We as a country are now paying our way. BREAK.PARA: Let me tell you about growth and confidence. It is 12 months since I first alerted this parliament to the potential of Townsville, Australia's largest tropical city. In the last year Townsville has surged ahead and has, I believe, a future brighter than any other Australian city. Confidence, expectation and action is everywhere—in industry, in commerce, in sport and in development. This confidence is built on a city and its people who recognise the opportunities ahead, people who are progressive, people who have a strong sense of community spirit.

Tonight I am proud to report about Townsville, the fastest growing regional area in the Commonwealth. Take, for example, Townsville's newest industry created in the last year: the sports and entertainment industry; an industry that is putting our city squarely and continually in the national spotlight. In football, our team, the North Queensland Cowboys, naturally play in the Super League. This has given us Stockland Stadium, a ground that is as good as any facility in Australia. It has brought the World Nines rugby league tournament to Townsville. The game boasts the biggest football crowds outside the Broncos in Australia. Talking of the Broncos, they could not beat us last weekend in Brisbane. The Cowboys held them to a 20‐all draw on their home ground. Great work, team!

In basketball, the Townsville Suns are burning up the National Basketball League. They are currently placed at a very credible third in the league competition. More than that, the Townsville team holds an Australian professional record of 58 consecutive home game sell‐outs. Every home game attracts 4,500 fans to the Townsville Entertainment Centre.

The state government budget today provided the funds to expand the capacity of the Entertainment Centre to some 6,000 seats. That is another $11 million into the Townsville economy and a further sign of confidence. In local basketball, work is also well under way on the $1.5 million upgrade to the Murray sporting complex.

In the past year, not one but two new power stations have been confirmed for Townsville. Initially, they will operate with LPG gas fuel but later they will likely be fed from a gas pipeline planned to bring the Chevron oil project gas from the Gulf of Papua all the way to Townsville.

Construction of the new $55 million minerals berth at the Townsville port is also well under way. This will service the export of the BHP Cannington project, the largest zinc deposit in the world. Also this year the port has recorded its ninth consecutive year of record trade, handling more than seven million tonnes of cargo. The Townsville Port Authority has also been proactive in moving to establish a new road/rail services port access corridor.

The Pandora dream was realised this year with the state government's firm commitment to the $17 million museum project. This was a coup for Townsville and will house the priceless Pandora shipwreck collection. At Townsville airport, international flights resumed to New Guinea. Milne Bay Air is servicing Townsville—one of the three international airports in Queensland. There has also been a growing business in fly in, fly out operations to the mines in north‐west Queensland.

James Cook University in Townsville continues to lead the world in marine science, sports science and earth science. That is right: I said that it leads the world in marine science, sports science and earth science. They garnered a whopping slice of the funding pie from the Australian Research Council large grants program announced last year.

I was concerned last year when I became aware that the project to provide a new northern gateway to the city—long promised by the previous government—had not been signed off, despite their assurances to the contrary. It took a lot of hard work but, with the outstanding support of the northern beach es community, Townsville secured the funding.

Last week I had the honour of moving the first soil on the new roadworks site. The commencement of these roadworks means a lot to Townsville, much more than the $21 million cost of the project. It has been talked about and discussed for years. That, in the end, was the problem. There was lots of talk, lots of promises but no action from the former government. Finally, the Howard coalition government has put action into all the words and all the promises. We have done that in our first year in government.

The Woolcock Street project will create about 100 jobs in the twin cities of Townsville and Thuringowa, and will pave the way for further roadworks in the future, particularly in improving the flood immunity of the Bruce Highway. The Townsville region is also seeing action in major coastal developments. The Oyster Point or Port Hinchinbrook project suffered from years of indecision and inaction on the part of the former government. It took the Howard government to say yes to Port Hinchinbrook and, in doing so, yes to jobs and regional development in North Queensland.

On Magnetic Island, I have been working hard behind the scenes to clear the way for the Nelly Bay Harbour project. Again, lack of leadership by the ALP forced years of delay on the project. We will deliver. The latest research shows that 82.7 per cent of our city supports the all‐weather harbour. Coalition governments at both state and federal levels are strongly behind the completion of the development. This is good news for Magnetic Island residents.

If you believed the comments of the opposition and the CPSU of late about the Public Service and Townsville, you would probably think the Public Service in Townsville has been gutted, but you would be wrong. In February this year, I had the pleasure of securing and then announcing 50 new jobs for Townsville's Department of Social Security teleservice centre. This was a major win for Townsville and, in particular, the Townsville City Heart business district.

The Townsville DSS teleservice centre will have doubled in staff numbers by September 1997, generating an estimated extra $1.5 million in additional wages in the City Heart area. The CPSU's Patrick Meikle would like the Townsville City Heart traders and his union members to believe that these 50 jobs are under threat and have not been budgeted for. I say to the Townsville City Heart small business men and women and to all CPSU members in Townsville that Mr Meikle is 100 per cent wrong. These jobs have been signed and sealed, and they will be delivered in full by the end of September. These 50 new jobs reflect the important role the Australian Public Service plays in Townsville and, in particular, reinforce the importance of Townsville as the major service centre in North Queensland.

I turn now to the Australian Defence Force, which also plays a major role in Townsville. Indeed, I would almost go so far as to say that the ADF is Townsville in many ways. Townsville is home to Australia's largest defence base and the operational defence force. Over the last 14 months the federal government has been investing heavily in the ADF in Townsville. In the next 12 months these investments will increase troop numbers in the city, create and sustain a substantial number of jobs, create a bonanza of subcontracting opportunities for local businesses and inject millions of dollars into the local economy.

Last week the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) announced Boeing Australia as the preferred tenderer for the ADF's new high frequency communications network system. The system will comprise new ground stations located in four centres across Australia. Of course, one of these centres is Townsville. I spoke with the Department of Defence about the impact of this project for Townsville. Defence estimates a flow-on effect of about $15 million into the Townsville economy in the form of jobs, equipment, software development, testing and systems support and management over the following years. The opportunity for local Townsville businesses to benefit through subcontracting arrangements is significant.

An estimated $14.3 million is to be spent this financial year on continuing construction and associated work tied to the relocation of 10 Terminal Regiment to Townsville. Upon completion of the project an estimated $26 million will have been spent relocating that regiment in Townsville, on the Ross River, bringing about a further 200 service personnel into the city. The flow-on effect to the local economy of this number of additional wage earners and their families coming to Townsville is enormous.

The ADF's helicopter fleet at RAAF Base Townsville will also start to receive new facilities this year. The construction of the $21 million helicopter shelters and wash facilities for 5 Aviation Regiment—the Black Hawk regiment—is expected to start in about three months time. Again, this project will generate jobs and work for local subcontractors.

The opposition spokesman for defence said earlier this year that the coalition had sold out the ADF in Townsville as a result of the defence efficiency review. Despite the whole focus of the DER redirecting resources to the operational, sharp end of the ADF—and it does not get any sharper than in Townsville—the opposition claimed the DER would lead to reductions in uniform numbers in the city. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to address a problem that concerns the people of Crescent Head in my electorate. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to put on the record tonight in this great place, pay respect to and recognise the great achievements of a very good friend, a brother and a great Australian. Etti Pau was born on 15 October 1921 on Darnley Island. His father, Jimmy, was a seaman from Murray Island. His mother, Gada, was from Darnley Island. He married Betty Cook, who is now deceased, on 23 August 1948. They had seven children: Maria, Elsie, Ray, Rebecca, Cyril, Bakoi and Thomas. He had 21 grandchildren and eight great‐grandchildren.

SPEECH.PARA: Etti grew up on Darnley Island and was one of the first soldiers to join up in 1941 when the first company, A Company, was formed of the Torres Strait Light Infantry Battalion. Soon after, almost every able-bodied man on Erub joined the Torres Strait Light Infantry Battalion. Etti was trained in combat and was involved in the building of a dam on Horn Island. It was during this time that he began to emerge as an activist for his people, strongly opposing injustices inflicted on them. He served in the army until 1946.

He returned to Darnley Island and served as a community police officer before a stint as a carpenter working for the Department of Native Affairs where he was involved in the building of the Bamaga settlement. In 1948 he and his brother, Daniel, purchased a crayfishing lugger, Rebecca, which they operated until 1957.

In 1967 he travelled to Canberra with fellow Torres Strait Islanders Elia Ware and Thomas Lowah to march with the Aboriginal people calling on the federal government to hold a referendum enabling indigenous people to have equal rights with other Australians. To raise the money to make this trip to Canberra, Etti launched an appeal on the local radio station. He spent each day in the lead-up to his trip asking passers-by to donate money into his bowler hat. This way of raising money he continued right until his death, as he travelled south to meet ministers lobbying them to improve conditions for his people. In fact, many of his trips were paid for with his pension and his own fundraising.

At the end of the war, he became the founding member of the Torres Strait Ex-Servicemen, holding the position of president from its inception until his recent death. As president of this organisation, he lobbied strongly on behalf of the valiant members of the 1st Torres Strait Light Infantry. Etti was an extremely active member of the communi ty, holding positions in many organisations in the Torres Strait. He was the founding member of the Torres Strait Housing Co-op, founding member of the Pasa Gabe Housing and Community Support Group in Cairns, a community councillor for Tamwoy and was on the organising committee of the Torres Strait Cultural Festival from 1989. He was awarded the OAM in recognition of his community achievements.

Etti's lobbying also resulted in the introduction of a student allowance and sole parent allowance for indigenous people. His lack of education did not deter him from taking on any person of authority, including Australia's Prime Minister. He, in fact, invited the Prime Minister of the day to visit Thursday Island, and he was very proud of that. He accompanied the Prime Minister on the visit to the Torres Strait.

Etti had been invited to speak at the reconciliation convention currently taking place at the World Congress Centre in Melbourne. Sadly, he passed away suffering from cancer at the Townsville Base Hospital in the early hours of Tuesday morning, 20 May. He is to be buried on Thursday Island in his beloved Torres Strait this Friday, 30 May.

I must say that I am most privileged to have been asked by his family to speak at his wake. I wear this colourful tie tonight in honour of my wonderful friend Etti Pau, depicting the three most important resources for the Torres Strait Island people: the dugong, the turtle and the magnificent reef. Finally, I would like to say Kaima Esso to Etti for all your hard work, commitment and dedication to your beautiful Torres Strait and your nation of Australia. Yawo to a dear friend. You will never be forgotten.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pyne, Chris, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The reasoned arguments in favour of lifting the ban on parallel imports of CDs have all been heard. Now it is the turn of the CD import monopolists—and all they can do is throw everything against the wall and hope and pray that something resonates. I cannot blame the big six music companies for defending so stoutly their golden acre, but it is high time we redrew the boundaries and distributed the benefits to the Australian consumers.

SPEECH.PARA: The latest attempt to preserve the status quo comes by way of a scare campaign—a three-pronged argument warning that the USA will no longer trade with us, that pirates will plunder us and our music market, and that Australian artists and our Australian cultural music identity will wither and die. These assertions are powerful, but blatantly false.

While it is true that the United States has sought an international agreement on import monopolies for some time, its mission has failed. Such an agreement is not part of the Berne, GATT or WTO conventions and import policies are clearly a matter for each individual nation. The US knows it is fighting a losing battle trying to impose trade restrictions on a world intent on removing all of the barriers.

The lifting of the ban on the parallel import of CDs does not mean that the market will be flooded with pirated music. Piracy will remain illegal; it will not be permissible to manufacture or import unauthorised compact discs. The demand for pirated product will be reduced as the price for the real thing comes down. The record stores are watched closely by the music companies and would likely detect very early any increases in piracy.

Artists are, to use the jargon, discovered and signed to recording contracts because they are seen as potential money-spinners. While sceptics have said that talent has little to do with this process, I maintain that the country of origin has even less. There will always be an Australian industry. Exposure in local entertainment outlets will guarantee that some performers are snapped up—perhaps first by the smaller independent labels and then later by the bigger concerns. That happens now and will continue to happen, no matter the nation's policy on parallel imports.

The ban on parallel imports does not protect the local industry or its jobs. There is no restriction on the quantity of compact discs for import. Rather, the restriction is confined to who may import them. As a consequence, the limited competition guarantees that Australian retail prices are far higher than they should be. The Australian consumers are being touched and the marketing gimmicks used by the music companies do not disguise that fact.

The number of Australians buying CDs direct from the US via the Internet does not hurt the monopolists at all. Their parent companies end up with the money anyway. The local CD stores, however—those employ ing people—are the ones who miss the boat. The reality of borderless trade is never better illustrated than as it is with the quick purchase and delivery of small consumer products on the Net—door‐to‐door delivery from anywhere in the world and cheaper than going to the local mall and, in some instances, quicker.

Clearly, it is time to change the law, time to lift the ban on parallel importing of CDs and time to end the dominance of the gang of six, who sell their wares at a low price in the United States but take advantage of arcane laws here to grab excessive profits from Australian consumers. On latest average retail figures, CDs in Australia are still over 40 per cent more expensive than in the USA. This makes little of the recently touted line that Australia has the best specials in the CD buying world.

It will be extremely disheartening to CD buyers if the import monopoly is allowed to continue. By dismantling the cartel and allowing parallel imports, we would boost competition, lower prices and surely provide a great boost to sales. There would, indeed, be few unhappy with that situation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 13 February 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is or was Mr Johannes Jacobsen a federal agent operating in WA; if so, for how long has he been employed in that capacity.

(2) Is he able to say whether on or about 24 January 1997 Mr Jacobsen ordered Miss Susan Stewart to stop distribution of any publication written by Dr Z.S. Jemielita; if so, (a) on what grounds and (b) upon whose authority.
(3) Did Mr Jacobsen or associates provide a transcript of a taped interview to the Judge as exhibit 63 in the trial of Dr Jemielita and his wife.
(4) Was the transcript put before the jury as part of the evidence for the deliberation of the jury.
(5) Is it permissible to tender transcripts of a tape when the tape itself is not available.
(6) Was the transcript made available to Dr Jemielita's defence beforehand; if not, how could the doctor refute it.
(7) Have 120 pages of the transcript been removed from the District Court records; if so, (a) was the transcript falsified and (b) why were the pages removed.
(8) Was the material removed following information from a member of his staff.

(9) Did an officer from the Australian Federal Police contact the Postmaster in Perth on telephone number 13 13 18 and request him not to accept Dr Jemielita's mail; if so (a) who was the officer and (b) why.
(10) Will he refer the matter of inadmissible and false evidence and other matters contained in the petition of Ann Vanstone QC to the Supreme Court of WA.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Federal Agent Jacobsen is an experienced member of the Australian Federal Police who has been working in Western Australia since 1980 on investigations into serious crime and major fraud, including Medicare fraud.
(2) I am advised that Federal Agent Jacobsen did not make any such approach to Miss Susan Stewart.

(3) Yes. During Dr Jemielita's trial the prosecution played a tape recording of the police interview of Dr Jemielita. The prosecution tendered this tape recording as exhibit 62. The prosecution also provided the trial Judge and the jury with a transcript of the tape recording as an aid to which they could refer whilst the tape recording was played during the trial. The prosecution tendered this transcript as exhibit 63. The judge also permitted the jury to have access to the tape and transcript during its final deliberations.

(4) Yes. The prosecution tendered the tapes of the record of interview as exhibit 62 as the primary evidence of the interview. The prosecution tendered the transcript of the recording as exhibit 63 to assist the judge and jury in understanding the tape recording.
(5) In this trial both the tapes and the transcript of the tapes were tendered.

(6) Yes, the prosecution made the transcript available to Dr Jemielita's defence by 19 October 1992, some 35 days before the trial commenced on 23 November 1992. The DPP also made the tape recording available to Dr Jemielita's defence by 5 November 1992, some 18 days before the trial commenced.
It was therefore open to Dr Jemielita to refute the transcript from, at the latest, 5 November 1992. At no time before the trial did Dr Jemielita attempt to refute the transcript.

The tape recording of the interview with Dr Jemielita was played during the trial. Throughout the trial and particularly when the tape recording was played to the court, Dr Jemielita and his counsel had every opportunity to refute any part of the transcript. At no time during the trial did Dr Jemielita or his counsel challenge the transcript's veracity.

On 8 January 1993 Dr Jemielita appealed to the Western Australian Full Court of Criminal Appeal against his conviction. The appeal was heard on 6 May 1993. At no time from 5 November 1992 up to or during the appeal did Dr Jemielita challenge the veracity of the transcript of the record of interview.

(7) The DPP is unable to say. The transcript was in the custody of the District Court from the trial which began in November 1992 until 12 June 1996 when the transcript was returned to Federal Agent Jacobsen, along with other exhibits in the trial. The DPP is not aware of any basis for the allegation that pages were removed and the transcript was falsified during the three and a half years it was in the custody of the District Court.
(8) Neither the AFP nor Federal Agent Jacobsen have any knowledge of this issue.

(10) A decision on whether the case should be referred to the Court of Criminal Appeal will be made once all the reports requested by the Attorney-General's Department have been received and the Departmental submission has been provided to me for consideration.
